title: What is the name of this city
content:
# What is the name of this city ## Frage

In Parshat Chukat, we have the following Pasuk:

וְלֹא־נָתַ֨ן סִיחֹ֣ן אֶת־יִשְׂרָאֵל֮ עֲבֹ֣ר בִּגְבֻלוֹ֒ וַיֶּאֱסֹ֨ף סִיחֹ֜ן אֶת־כָּל־עַמּ֗וֹ וַיֵּצֵ֞א לִקְרַ֤את יִשְׂרָאֵל֙ הַמִּדְבָּ֔רָה וַיָּבֹ֖א יָ֑הְצָה וַיִּלָּ֖חֶם בְּיִשְׂרָאֵֽל׃

Targum Onkelos and the Targum on the Torah that is attributed to Yonasan ben Uziel; (is that really Targum Yonasan?) both translate the word יהצה as ליהץ, meaning that the name of the place is יהץ and the ה suffix has the same function as a ל prefix.

However, there is a Pasuk in Shoftim that clearly says the name of the city was יהצה; not יהץ (Shoftim 11:20):

וְלֹא־הֶאֱמִ֨ין סִיח֤וֹן אֶת־יִשְׂרָאֵל֙ עֲבֹ֣ר בִּגְבֻל֔וֹ וַיֶּאֱסֹ֤ף סִיחוֹן֙ אֶת־כׇּל־עַמּ֔וֹ וַֽיַּחֲנ֖וּ בְּיָ֑הְצָה וַיִּלָּ֖חֶם עִם־יִשְׂרָאֵֽל׃

If the name was really יהץ, then in the Pasuk above, it should have said ביהץ. (Even תרגום יונתן over there says ביהצה; not ביהץ.)

It would seem to me that the name of the place was really יהצה. Why did the Targumim in our Parsha decide to say that the place was really called יהץ?

(One may say that it doesn't make sense grammatically to say, "and he arrived, יהצה;" so we were forced to say that the ה was a suffix meaning "to."

However, we have another instance of that sentence structure in a very similar context:

וַיִּפְנוּ֙ וַֽיַּעֲל֔וּ דֶּ֖רֶךְ הַבָּשָׁ֑ן וַיֵּצֵ֣א עוֹג֩ מֶֽלֶךְ־הַבָּשָׁ֨ן לִקְרָאתָ֜ם ה֧וּא וְכָל־עַמּ֛וֹ לַמִּלְחָמָ֖ה אֶדְרֶֽעִי׃

Here there's no ה at the end to say it means "to Edrei," so we see that grammatically we can say "he arrived, יהצה."

Additionally, if we say it's a suffix in our Parsha, then we'd be left with a contradiction between the two Pesukim.

I guess my question is, what is the correct name of the city? (Also, does the fact that it's מלעיל mean it has to be a suffix?)

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 6)

tl;dr: The city was called both יהץ and יהצה, and by the time of the targums' authors, it was probably more commonly referred to as יהץ.

It should first be noted that there are a couple of places where יהצה is called יהץ (Yeshayahu 15:4, Yirmiyahu 48:34).

Several toponyms in Tanach can be found both with a final letter Heh and without:

  • אבלה - אבל (Shmuel 2:20:14-15 and ibid. 2:20:18)
  • אכזיבה - אכזיב (Yehoshua 19:29 and Shoftim 1:31)
  • אפרתה - אפרת (e.g. Beresheet 35:19 and ibid. 48:7)
  • בצרה - בצר (e.g. Devarim 4:43 and Yirmiyahu 48:24)
  • דבירה - דביר (Yehoshua 10:3 and ibid. 10:39)
  • יזרעאלה - יזרעאל (Yehoshua 17:16 and ibid. 19:18)
  • עגלונה - עגלון (Yehoshua 10:36 and ibid. 10:37)
  • שבמה - שבם (Bamidbar 32:3 and ibid. 32:38)

and so forth. The above citations are to places where it's clear that the Heh isn't a suffix meaning direction (to [place X]) but rather part of the root of the toponym itself, along with examples of the same toponyms without a final Heh.

Ben-Tzion Eshel, 'Dialects and Pronunciations according to Biblical Names' (להגים והגיות לפי שמות שבמקרא), in: Menachem Haran and Ben-Tzion Luria (eds.), Sefer Tur-Sinai, Jerusalem 5720, pp. 263-264 concluded based on the above list (along with several other examples) that the affixed Heh was born from a Hebraic tendency to elongate or drag out the pronunciation of some words (compare certain English dialects such as the American southern drawl).

In other words, יהצה was at the same time both יהצה and יהץ, largely dependent on the speaker. Given that it is more commonly referred to as יהצה, it's possible that more Israelites referred to it as יהצה. However, it seems that the version יהץ (Yahatz) was the one used by the local Moabites: In the Mesha Stele, the form יהצ appears twice (see here). While the starting point of usage of mater lectionis (אימות הקריאה) among both Moabites, Israelites and other contemporary Hebrew-dialect-speaking ethnic groups is highly debatable, it seems likely that the Moabite scribe of the inscription intended Yahatz rather than Yahatzah (with an "invisible" final Heh, the /a/ sound at the end merged into the final letter Tzadi). Evidence for this likely pronunciation comes from other toponyms and names in general in the inscription that show that Moabites did use Heh as an affix: Davidoh (דודה), Nevoh (נבה = Nevo - נבו), Korchah (קרחה), etc. Given that, it seems that were the Moabite pronunciation (or at least that of the 9th century BCE) had been Yahatzah (יהצה), they would have included a final Heh.

Some suppose that יהצה (and other names with a final Heh) is a more archaic form that was gradually filtered out of spoken language, until finally it was only preserved in textual traditions.1 We do not know how the Moabites pronounced יהצה/יהץ prior to the 9th century, but it's possible that the appearance of יהצ in 9th century Moav reflects the beginning of the transition from יהצה to יהץ among Hebraic people.

This is a phenomenon often known as ניוון השפה (the degeneracy of the language). Over the centuries and millennia we find a significant expansion of this phenomenon in the Hebrew used by Israelites/Jews. For example, by the time Targum Onkelos was created, elongated pronunciation was less common in Hebrew (and Hebrew in general was used less on a daily basis). In fact, we find more and more of the reverse phenomenon: The syncopated Heh, whereby a final Heh or a definitive Heh (ה"א הידיעה) was "swallowed" up by the preceding letter, leading to more condensed pronunciations. This phenomenon was born out of the development of a faster colloquial manner of speaking.2 Especially in Eretz Yisrael we find that by the time of Chazal, fast, condensed colloquial pronunciations were very widespread. A good example of this is the fact that in the Yerushalmi the names אלעזר (Elazar) and אליעזר (Eliezer) are usually spelled לעזר (Lazar) and ליעזר (Liezer), and יהודה (Yehudah) is usually spelled יודן (Yudan).3

So, in response to the question of the city's name: It was both יהץ and יהצה, depending on who used the toponym, and when. However, it is important to note that the version יהצה occasionally featured a final Heh as a directive, i.e., "to Yahatz(ah)" can be written either as ליהץ or יהצה. Lena-Sofia Tiemeyer, 'A New Look at the Biological Sex/Grammatical Gender of Jonah’s Fish', Vetus Testamentum 67 (2017) noted two cases in which יהצה in Tanach probably denotes direction, Bamidbar 21:23 and Yirmiyahu 48:21. My guess is that by the time the targums were authored, the more commonly-used form of the city's name was the shorter יהץ, matching the general degenerated state of the Hebrew of the time. These two points explain why יהצה in Bamidbar 21:23 was translated by both Onkelos and Pseudo-Yonatan as ליהץ rather than ליהצה.

1 See in Eshel's article as well as here, p. 14; note that in Greek sources the form was always ιασσα (Iassa), which reflects יהצה (so in the LXX and Eusebius's Onomasticon).

2 On the phenomenon in the Tanachic period, see here, p. 7; on the phenomenon in Judean Hebrew (ca. 2nd century CE) see Uri Mor, Judean Hebrew: The Language of the Hebrew Documents from Judea between the First and Second Revolts (עברית יהודאית: לשון התעודות העבריות ממדבר יהודה בין המרד הגדול למרד בר כוכבא), Jerusalem 5776, pp. 72-75. IY"H later this year an article I wrote related to this topic is supposed to be published. I will update Be"H.

3 For one discussion of the topic and the possible reasons for the development of what scholars term "עברית מנוונת" (degenerated Hebrew), see here.

title: On the Rambam's view on funding Torah scholars
content:
# On the Rambam's view on funding Torah scholars ## Frage

Maimonides rejected the notion that Jews must help financially other Jews to study Torah:

All this is wrong. There is not a single word, either in the Torah or in what the Sages said, to lend credence to it... As we look into the sayings of the Talmudic sages, we do not find that they ask people for money, nor did they collect money for the honorable and cherished academies. [On Avot 4:5]

But that claim is not quite true. In the Talmud [Pesachim 53b], we read:

Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Anyone who casts merchandise into the purse of Torah scholars is rewarded and sits in the Heavenly Academy, as it it said: "For in the shadow of wisdom is the shadow of money." [Ecclesiastes 7:12]

While this is not a request for money, it is certainly strong encouragement to donate, powered by a promise of rewards in the World to Come. Did the Rambam not know that and are there other ancient sources of funding scholars?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 7)

The Rambam quotes that Gemara word for word in later in that comment. He explains it as "That you allow them to sell their products first in the market" not giving them cash. The Rambam also codifies this in Talmud Torah 6:10.

The Meiri explains that Gemara that one should become a business partner with the sage (and written by the Rambam in this comment). Note that the Rambam did this himself early in his life where he sat and studied all day and invested his money with his brother.

title: Learning Torah From A Person Who Learns Not Lishma
content:
# Learning Torah From A Person Who Learns Not Lishma ## Frage

I’m wondering if there’s any source/mention about learning Torah from someone who learns Torah not lishma. Specifically not lishma from honour. What I mean is, while it’s impossible to know one’s true intentions, you can sometimes “tell” that someone is just doing it for honour and Im wondering if you can learn from such a person

This question is based on the principle that one should not learn Torah from a heretic (lehavdil) and the story with Rabbi Meir and Acher and how he was able to learn from him because he could pick out the good and throw out the bad but not everyone can do that. We learn that Torah is not just about the knowledge that is transmitted it’s also about the receptacle from which it is being transmitted. Therefore I feel the question of learning from someone who is only learning for the sake of honour (they want to boast their knowledge even at the expense of putting other people down) may have some source but I haven’t found anything

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Obviously if one has a choice, he follows the best possible teacher who "is like an angel" (see explanations here). Ribbi Meir says that one is allowed to study from an imperfect teacher, since he is learning not "his (the teacher's) wisdom, but My (Hashem's) wisdom" (Hagigah 15b).

Although I don't have a source for this particular case of not lishma, there is a source for something worse.

One is not allowed to charge for teaching the oral torah, but if one cannot find a teacher who will teach him for free he should pay (B'chorot 29a).

This is even though this teacher is not following the law himself. A fair assumption is if the teacher is not following the actual law, he does not study lishmah.

title: Vilna Gaon - Torah can bring you up or bring you down
content:
# Vilna Gaon - Torah can bring you up or bring you down ## Frage

Does anyone know the source of the Vilna Gaon talking about Torah and saying that it can either be used for the good or for the bad, it depends on one’s midot. He said that Torah is like rain. If you have good midot (a good seed) and learn Torah then it is constructive. But if you have bad midot and learn Torah it will be even more destructive because Torah learning on its own has power, and whichever way you lead it that’s where you go. So therefore one should put heavy focus on his midot to make sure when he learns Torah he builds something constructive and not the opposite chas

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 8)

This teaching of the Vilna Gaon is quoted in Even Sheleimah #47:

ענין התורה לנפש דוגמת המטר לארץ שמצמיח מה שנזרע בה סם חיים או סם מות. כן בתורה מצמיח מה שבלבו אם לבו טוב תגדיל יראתו. ואם בלבו שורש פורה ראש ולענה יגדיל הטינא בלבו ... ע"כ צריך לפנות לבו בכל יום קודם הלימוד ואחריו מעיפוש הדיעות והמדות ביראת חטא ומע"ט

The Torah's effect on the soul is like that of rain on the ground, in that it causes whatever is planted there to grow, whether good or bad. So too, the Torah causes whatever is in a person's heart to grow. If he is good-hearted, the Torah will increase his piety. But if his heart contains the seeds of bad behavior, the bitterness in his heart will only increase ... Therefore, every day, before and after learning, one has to cleanse his heart from poor behaviors, with increased piety and good deeds.

(my own fairly free translation)

As noted in the reference there, this is based on a number of passages in the Gaon's commentary to Mishlei, primarily Mishlei 24:31.

title: How Moshe handled halachic disputes
content:
# How Moshe handled halachic disputes ## Frage

I heard about a source in the Chumash regarding a situation where two people had a halachic dispute and could not conclude on the Halacha. They then went to Moshe to get the verdict but the wording of the verse says it in the singular to show that only one of them actually went to Moshe. The commentaries from here learned that it is good practice to act in this manner and if two people are really having this argument (whether financial or otherwise) for the sake of heaven then this is the way they should act to prove that they are really only after the “Dvar Hashem” and not to fight to prove that he is right

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Wow B”H I found the answer after some extensive research Baruch Hashem! For anyone else looking , the source for this teaching is from Parashat Yitro 18:16

כִּֽי־יִהְיֶ֨ה לָהֶ֤ם דָּבָר֙ בָּ֣א אֵלַ֔י וְשָׁ֣פַטְתִּ֔י בֵּ֥ין אִ֖ישׁ וּבֵ֣ין רֵעֵ֑הוּ וְהוֹדַעְתִּ֛י אֶת־חֻקֵּ֥י הָאֱלֹהִ֖ים וְאֶת־תּוֹרֹתָֽיו׃

When they have a dispute, it comes before me, and I decide between one party and another, and I make known the laws and teachings of God.”

On this verse Malbim, Gur Aryeh Divrei David and possibly more comment on the fact that the verse starts plural and then switches to singular and explain this exact principle. Divrei David actually wants to explain this using the Gemara in Bava Metzia 69a

B”H from my asking around I can see that this is not a very revealed teaching and I am very blessed to have originally heard it from a shiur so I tremendously hope it will now be able to reach others and we should keep sharing Torah with each other

title: Genesis | Why weren't other land creatures blessed on the 6th day?
content:
# Genesis | Why weren't other land creatures blessed on the 6th day? ## Frage

I've been looking over the creation with an eye towards the 10 utterances of creation ("Then God said...") and other instances where God spoke or blessed something.

In Genesis 1:22, God blesses the creatures of the sea and the birds of the air - and says to be fruitful and multiply.

In Genesis 1:29, God blesses mankind - and says to be fruitful and multiply, to fill the earth and subdue it, and to rule over all other creatures in the earth and seas and the birds of the air.

In Genesis 2:3, God blesses the 7th day and sanctifies it - but notably it is not written that he says anything on this occasion.

What I find interesting here is that during the creation creatures of the sea and the birds of the air and man were all blessed - but other creatures made on the 6th day were NOT blessed. Why were they denied a blessing?

I also just noticed something else interesting (but not part of the question): there are precisely 12 occurrences during the creation where it is written that God said something; 2 of them being blessings.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Rashi on Genesis 1:22 writes that G-d chose not to bless the land animals, as that would have included blessing the soon-to-be-accursed serpent.

Ramban ad loc. suggests that the blessing of the fish on the fifth day applied to the land animals as well.

Genesis Rabbah 11:3 (at least according to some interpretations) considers the blessing of man on the sixth day to also apply to the animals created on the sixth day.

title: Should we thank AI the way Moses was thankful to the Nile?
content:
# Should we thank AI the way Moses was thankful to the Nile? ## Frage

There are sources1,2 that say that Moshe was commanded to not hit the Nile to initiate the plague of blood, nor hit the sand to initiate the plague of lice, because he had benefited from them (and therefore should be grateful - see Sefer Chassidim 665 on the importance of gratitude, even to animals).

Even though we are talking about inanimate objects, it is still proper to always act in a way that is in consonance with good middot, and striking the Nile would have therefore been inappropriate.

Can we learn from this that it is proper for every God fearing Jew to say thank you to AI LLMs once they have answered our questions? What about passively refraining from being rude when "conversing" with the LLM?

I ask about these rather than simply thanking any technology for its use because they do make us "feel" like we are interacting with a human, and therefore it is in consonance with good middot to say thank you for the help provided, even though it is inanimate.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 8)

Regarding thanking, we don't see Moshe thanking them ever, just not plaguing them (maybe the source of the Sefer Hasidim would be "from a negative, you can infer a positive (opposite)" (Sotah 17a), see also Michtav m'Eliyahu 3 pg 100 about being grateful to inanimate objects). A better source would be Taanit 5b, where one thanks a tree, but its only used as an example to thank another person so I don't think that's a good proof. (Side note, back when you would have to say "hey google, stop" to stop a time, I would say thank you instead but now that I can just blurt out stop, it's a lot easier and I do that.)

In regards to being rude, that would probably fall under a category similar to speaking Lashon Hara about a non-Jew. There is much discussion about that already. One can argue that this is even worse since the AI cannot be an idol worshipper whereas non-Jews are assumed to be. (My grandfather used to call Google ידעוני - eg know it all, I can assume he would consider AI the same). The Rambam (8 P'rakim 4, see De'ot 2:6) writes that our character traits get ingrained in us by repeating the same thing again and again. This would imply that one should not get used to speaking rudely, this would apply to AI too.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

I recently heard a Shalosh Seides Torah from from R' Shie Fink from Bnei Brak, who explained that Moshe Rabbeini's Hakoras Hatoiv (not necessarily thanking but feeling grateful) was about being a "Hakoras Hatoiv person" meaning that he didn't hit the river because that would make him into an ungrateful person (on his level), and as R' Shie explained, this applies to everything in every situation, therefore according to this you might not have to actually thank the AI, but definitely should feel grateful to it.

(He brought sources & stories for all of it but I dont remember it all.)

(Also, he connected it with the Belzer Ruv (R' Aharon) who wouldn't speak or hear a word spoken against Eretz Yisroel, explaining that it's not about what you speak against, but more about the speaker himself being a person who speaks in such a way.)

### Antwort 3 (Score: 1)

The question is whether one should express thanks to AI just as Moshe Rabbeinu showed hakarat hatov by not hitting the Nile.

There are several aspects that go into answering this question:

  1. Moshe Rabbeinu did not say thank you to the Nile as far as we know (please let me know if there is such a source). So from this there is no indication that one should actively thank the inanimate object which helped him.

  2. There is what to say for the importance of one working on his middot and not letting himself to be trained in a negative middah (such as ungratefulness). This idea is demonstrated by the story with R' Shimon Ben Shatach telling his son not to switch what he was asking his wife for so as not to train himself in falsehood (if anyone has the source for this story I'm happy to add it in bl"n).

  3. There are many articles discussing the amount of resources wasted as a result of saying please and thank you and being polite in wording to AI. It seems that we should not be proactively advocating to do so if not necessary or positive in a spiritual way.

Putting all of these together: as there is no demonstrated requirement to actually verbalize the thanks, it would be enough to think the appreciation, thereby maintaining your middot while not wasting resources.

title: When is 40 years before the destruction of the 2nd Temple?
content:
# When is 40 years before the destruction of the 2nd Temple? ## Frage

We read in the Jerusalem Talmud:

"Forty years before the destruction of the Temple, the western light went out, the crimson thread remained crimson, and the lot for the Lord always came up in the left hand. They would close the gates of the Temple by night and get up in the morning and find them wide open" (Jacob Neusner, The Yerushalmi, p.156-157).

A similar passage in the Babylonian Talmud states:

"Our rabbis taught: During the last forty years before the destruction of the Temple the lot ['For the Lord'] did not come up in the right hand; nor did the crimson-colored strap become white; nor did the western most light shine; and the doors of the Hekel [Temple] would open by themselves" (Soncino version, Yoma 39b).

The 2nd Temple was destroyed in 70 CE August on Tisha B'Av. So when is 40 years before it? Was it 30 CE or 31 CE? Those who favor 31 CE say that Jews generally count the first year as well.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

עבודה זרה ט ע"ב records that the year 4231 לבה״ע (*not accounting for שנת תוהו which adds 1) was THREE years later than "FOUR HUNDRED years after the Temple's destruction", which means that the destruction of the Temple must have occurred in 4231 - 403 years = 3828 לבה״ע.

​אמר רבי חנינא: "אחר ארבע מאות לחורבן הבית, אם יאמר לך אדם 'קח שדה שוה אלף דינרים בדינר אחד'—לא תקח!" במתניתא תנא: "אחר ארבעת אלפים ומאתים ושלשים ואחת שנה לבריאת עולם, אם יאמר לך אדם 'קח לך שדה שוה אלף דינרים בדינר אחד'—אל תקח!" מאי בינייהו? איכא בינייהו תלת שנין דמתניתא טפיא תלת שני׃

*However, the Jewish calendar actually begins almost a full year BEFORE the creation of Man, because אדם הראשון is considered to have been created on 1st Tishri of Year 2, the first five of the ששת ימי בראשית being deemed as the last five days of Ellul of Year 1 - known as the Void Year (שנת תוהו, because all but its last six days were before anything existed) - following the principle "יום אחד בשנה חשוב שנה" (e.g. ראש השנה ב ע"ב, נידה מה ע"א).

And Hebrew dates exceed the corresponding civil dates by 3760 years for dates between the beginning of January and the end of אלול (the difference is 3761 years from the beginning of תשרי to the end of December), so it follows that the Temple was destroyed in the summer of 3828 + 1 − 3760 years = 69 CE. And 40 years before that would have been 3789 by our calendar or 29 CE.

title: Yehoshua: a leader or a shepherd?
content:
# Yehoshua: a leader or a shepherd? ## Frage

In Bamidbar 27:16, we read that Moshe pleads to G-d that He will set a leader over the Jewish People that will continue to lead them:

Let the L-rd, the G-d of the spirits of all flesh, set a man over the congregation

The reason the Torah gives us is so that B'nei Yisroel will have a shepherd that leads "the flock" (v. 17):

who may go out before them, and who may go in before them, and who may lead them out, and may bring them in; that the congregation of the L-rd be not as sheep that have no shepherd.

In Chabad-Chassidus, the concept that Moshe Rabbeinu is the faithful shepherd of the Jewish people, is discussed in many maamorim from different Rebbeim. The Rebbe talks about this in Maamar VeAtat Tetzaveh, 5741. He also quotes the Rebbe Raayatz in the Mamaar "VeKibeil HaYehudim". It is explained that:

a) a faithful shepherd of the Jewish people means that he faithfully tends to the needs of the Jewish people b) a shepherd of faith means that he sustains and nurtures the faith of the Jewish people.

Both terms apply to the description of Moshe Rabbeinu as the "raaya mehemna".

However, I found something interesting.

The Chida, in his Pnei David, writes that the meaning of the posuk "Let the L-rd, the G-d of the spirits of all flesh, set a man over the congregation" is that:

It is possible that the manner of the leader is that he goes ahead of the people, whereas the manner of a shepherd is that he follows the flock. Our Sages, may their memory be blessed, have also said this.

The Chida goes on to quote different meforshim that say that our posuk, al-pi-peshat, refers to when the people are going out to war. Then they need a leader.

Based on the idea that a leader goes "ahead of the people", whereas a shepherd "follows his flock". How can we interpret Moshe's plea to G-d that the Jewish people? It would seem that they need someone like Moshe, like tending his flock, and not leading people in case of war.

They needed someone who nurtures the faith, and not prepare them for war. Right? Any ideas on this?

title: Laughing-Gate cover up
content:
# Laughing-Gate cover up ## Frage

Moshe Rabbeinu was told that he can’t go into the holy land due to the incident with the water. We have other people who got into major trouble for seemingly doing something pretty valid or small things. Miriam is another example. Yaakov Avinu calling Esav his Lord etc. (Yes, there is a concept of Tzaddikim being held to a higher standard.)

Now let's go back to the incident where Sarah Immeinu laughs when being told that she was going to have a kid. That’s seem like a pretty big no-no to laugh at.

It seems like that’s a pretty serious thing to do; laughing at a divine statement. But she never got into trouble (Thank goodness, or else we all might not be here today!)

Did it ever occur to you, or maybe it is written down that what happened was a sort of nepotistic favor that unfolded where G_d looked away from what happened, because he really wanted Yitzchak Avinu to be born?

Was this entire ‘laughing-gate’ swept under the rug, because the one above needed things moving and the last thing he would want is to get Sarah Immeinu into trouble and mess it up for himself by delaying Yitzchak Avinu’s birth? (Yes, I know that G_d is not a human, to behave and act like a human but there are plenty of incidents, in the kabbalistic lexicons, where it does seem like he reacts like a human would have).

Was there some sort of ‘laughing-gate’ cover up?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

It seems like that’s a pretty serious thing to do; laughing at a divine statement. But she never got into trouble

According to some commentators, Sarah was indeed punished for laughing.

According the Midrash (see Rashi on Gen. 25:1, and BT BM 87a), there were cynics that suspected that it was Abhimelekh who had impregnated Sarah. R. Shim'on Sofer suggests that Sarah suffering such claims was a punishment for her laughing (see Shir Ma'on, p. 18).

Another Midrash (Pirqe de-Rabi Eli'ezer 32) relates that Samael (Satan) tricked Sarah into believing that Yishaq had been killed by Abhraham at the Aqeda and thus precipitated her death. The Hatham Sofer (citing the Panaeah Raza) suggests this was a punishment for laughing (see Oroth Hatham Sofer, p. 105).

title: Text different from details of an event
content:
# Text different from details of an event ## Frage

In Bereshit (Genesis) - Chapter 18, pasuk 13 says, 'And the Lord said to Abraham, "Why did Sarah laugh, saying, 'Is it really true that I will give birth, although I am old?''

Rashi on this pasuk says: וַֽאֲנִי זָקַֽנְתִּי: שִׁנָּה הַכָּתוּב מִפְּנֵי הַשָּׁלוֹם, שֶׁהֲרֵי הִיא אָמְרָה וַאדֹנִי זָקֵן: although I am old: Scripture altered [her statement] for the sake of peace, for she had said, “and my master is old.” - [from B.M. 87a]

I heard of spelling a word a certain way but pronouncing it another; but it seems this is the only place where one thing happened but something else was written down.

Can anyone share other pasukim, or incidents where one thing transpired but some thing else was written down?

Disclaimer: As the Alter Rebbe says, the Universe belongs to the Great one above, and he can obviously do, say, and ofcourse write what he wants.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

In parshas Ki Sisa (Shemos 32:22) Aharon’s account of the eigel is markedly different than the Torah’s. This too seems to be מפני השלום.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

Bereshit 12:18:

ויקרא פרעה לאברם ויאמר מה־זאת עשית לי למה לא־הגדת לי כי אשתך הוא

And Par῾o called Avram, and said, What is this that thou hast done to me? why didst thou not tell me that she was thy wife?

It is highly unlikely Pharaoh spoke Lashon Hakodesh. Especially when speaking to fellow Egyptians in 41:9 onwards.

title: Difficult time in life
content:
# Difficult time in life ## Frage

What if someone is going through a very difficult and uncertain period of life right now with serious concerns such as about money, not being married, profound anxiety about the future, etc. What can one do to have more emunah and bitachon to help get through this?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

This is a question depending on the person but I'll give it a shot.

I feel like there is a misconception about what bitachon is (partly thanks to the story of R Yisrael Salanter and the gold watch).

My grandfather, Rav Eliezer Ben-David, would explain 2 puzzling verses in Ashrei (Tehillim 145:19-20).

רְצוֹן־יְרֵאָיו יַעֲשֶׂה וְאֶת־שַׁוְעָתָם יִשְׁמַע וְיוֹשִׁיעֵם׃ שׁוֹמֵר יְהֹוָה אֶת־כׇּל־אֹהֲבָיו

Love of Hashem is greater than fear of Hashem (Sotah 31a). Yet the verse only says Hashem does the desires of those who fear him, those who love his get protection but not their desires. Hashem gives those who fear him what they want so they continue fearing him, this is sometimes to their detriment (such as saving a city because of Lot's prayer but Lot ending up in a cave with his daughters B'reshit 19:18-38). The one who loves Hashem will not question Hashem when he doesn't get his desired response, so Hashem may not listen to him in the first place for his own benefit.

The source of Emunah is being happy with what one has (see Avot 4:1). The opening line of Mesillat Yesharim is

יִּתְבָּרֵר וְיִתְאַמֵּת אֵצֶל הָאָדָם מָה חוֹבָתוֹ בְּעוֹלָמוֹ

a man has to clarify and come to realize as truth what is his obligation in his world

His world is his own world, what he has, not what he wants to have. Some people unfortunately don't get the best portion in this world (like the ibn Ezra). One should focus on all the good that Hashem does give him that

Even if our mouths were filled with song like the sea, and our tongues with exultation like the roaring of its waves, and our lips with praise like the breadth of the firmament, and our eyes were radiant like the sun and the moon, and our hands outspread like [the] eagles of the sky, and our feet light as the deer— we would never sufficiently thank You Hashem (Nishmat Kol Hai).

title: Did the Kings of Simien ever try to reach out to the Sanhedrin once it was finally formed?

title: What is the holiest "thing" ever?
content:
# What is the holiest "thing" ever? ## Frage

Obviously besides for God Himself, and also perhaps the greatest tzadiqim (righteous people) in history, what else is considered the holiest "thing" ever? (Is it the two luhoth (tablets)? If yes, please offer either a source or an explanation why.)

Please excuse the term "thing" in this question, I simply can't think of a better word. If you can please share!

The practical application to this question would be to give priority to save said "thing" from desecration.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

The Mishnah teaches that there are ten degrees of holiness in Judaism. [Kelim 1:5-9] Many examples are given. Broadly speaking:

-The Land of Israel is holier than all other lands.

-Jerusalem is holier than other cities in the Land.

-Temple Mount is holier than other parts of Jerusalem.

-The Holy of Holies is holier than other parts of the Temple.

-And the holiest place in the Holy of Holies is the point centered above the Ark, between the Keruvim, the cherubs, from which the Voice of God emanates.

title: Canonization of Tanakh
content:
# Canonization of Tanakh ## Frage

Given that the Talmud records disputes among great chachamim about the status of certain books of Ketuvim, how can we be fully confident that these books are in fact authoritative and true?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

The people deciding the canonization seemed to have been the Anshei knesset hagdolah (see Avot d'Ribbi Natan 1:4), included in them were the last of the prophets (Avot d'Ribbi Natan 1:3). Being prophets, they knew had some form of confirmation from Hashem on what they were saying and what they decided (like when they tried to say Shlomo has no portion in the world to come Bamidbar Rabbah 14:1). Being the last of the prophets, they closed off the text of Tanach (no Maccabees or New Testament) and may have rejected certain previous books such as Wars of Hashem, Divrei Hayamim of the Kings of Israel, Ben Sira (see Seder HaDorot), Sefer Hanoch, and I assume there are more.

The Tumah status of certain books were discussed later (Yadayim 3:5) but not in regards to them being authorative or not.

title: In Exodus 1:15, is there a reason that the names of the midwives are specified?
content:
# In Exodus 1:15, is there a reason that the names of the midwives are specified? ## Frage

Q: In Exodus 1:15, is there a reason that the names of the midwives are specified?:

15The king of Egypt spoke to the Hebrew midwives, one of whom was named Shiphrah and the other Puah, 16saying, “When you deliver the Hebrew women, look at the birthstool: if it is a boy, kill him; if it is a girl, let her live.” 17The midwives, fearing God, did not do as the king of Egypt had told them; they let the boys live. 18So the king of Egypt summoned the midwives and said to them, “Why have you done this thing, letting the boys live?” 19The midwives said to Pharaoh, “Because the Hebrew women are not like the Egyptian women: they are vigorous. Before the midwife can come to them, they have given birth.” 20And God dealt well with the midwives; and the people multiplied and increased greatly. 21And because the midwives feared God, He established households for them. 22Then Pharaoh charged all his people, saying, “Every boy that is born you shall throw into the Nile, but let every girl live.”

Jewish Publication Society. (1985). Tanakh: The Holy Scriptures (Ex 1:15–22). Jewish Publication Society.

Is there something in the etymology of the names? Do we know of them in other contexts? Or do they tell us something about people with whom they are connected?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

According to the Midrash Shemos Rabba 1:13 the names are given to express merits of the two women in saving lives of the Jewish children. Their effort is truely remarkable because only because of them and other righteous women we had true shvatim coming out of the Egyptian bondage.

“The king of Egypt said to the Hebrew midwives, of whom the name of one was Shifra and the name of the other was Pu’a” (Exodus 1:15).

When he saw that they were procreating, he issued a decree against the males – that is what is written: “The king of Egypt said to the midwives….” Who were the midwives? Rav said: A daughter-in-law and her mother-in-law, Yokheved and Elisheva daughter of Aminadav. Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥman says: A woman and her daughter, Yokheved and Miriam.

And Miriam was no more than five years old, as Aaron was three years older than Moses. Our Rabbis, of blessed memory, said: She would go with her mother Yokheved and assist her, and she was very quick. While the child is still young, his [character] is recognizable. That is what Solomon said: “Even a lad is recognized through his deeds” (Proverbs 20:11).

“…the name of one was Shifra [and the name of the other was Pu’a],” because she would attend to [meshaperet] the baby when he would emerge covered in blood; “Pu’a,” because she would express [nofa’at] wine into the babies after her mother [had attended to them].

Alternatively, Shifra, because Israel procreated [sheparu veravu] in her day; Pu’a, who would revive [mapia] the baby when they would say it was dead. Alternatively, Shifra, because she made her actions pleasing [shipera] before God; Pu’a, because she caused Israel to appear [hofia] before God. Alternatively, Pu’a, because she was impudent [hofia panim] to Pharaoh and had her nose in the air toward him, and she said to him: ‘Woe unto that man when God will come and punish him.’ He became filled with fury and sought to kill her. Shifra, because she eased [meshaperet] the words of her daughter and placated him toward her. She said to him: ‘Are you paying attention to her? She is a child and knows nothing.’

Rabbi Ḥanina bar Rav Yitzḥak said: Shifra, because she preserved Israel for God, and it was for their sake that the heavens were created, regarding which it is written: “By his wind the heavens are calm [shifra]” (Job 26:13). Pu’a, because she was impudent [hofia panim] toward her father. Amram was the head of the Sanhedrin at that time. Once Pharaoh issued his decree and said: “Every son that is born you shall cast him into the Nile” (Exodus 1:22), Amram said: ‘Isn’t Israel begetting children for naught?’ Immediately, he separated from Yokheved and abstained from sexual relations. He divorced his wife when she was three months pregnant. All Israel arose and divorced their wives. His daughter said to him: ‘Your decree is harsher than Pharaoh’s, as Pharaoh decreed only against the males, and you, against the males and the females. Pharaoh is wicked and it is uncertain whether his decree will be fulfilled or whether it will not be fulfilled. However, you are righteous and your decree will be fulfilled.’ He arose and remarried his wife. All Israel arose and remarried their wives. That is Pu’a, who was impudent toward her father.

Another midrash Koheles Rabba 7.1.3 recounts the deeds of the midwives and gives the punchline that OP is asking about:

Rabbi Yehuda said: Miriam and Yokheved were the midwives of the Israelites. As it is written: “The name of one was Shifra and the name of the second was Pu’a” (Exodus 1:15). Shifra, this is Yokheved, who would tend to [mishaperet] the children. Alternatively, it is because she procreated [shepara verava]. Alternatively, it is because the Israelites procreated due to her. Alternatively, it is because they bettered [shiperu] [the Israelite women] with mitzvot and good deeds. Alternatively, Shifra [is the name given her] as praise [of her character], as it is stated: “With His breath the heavens were calmed [shifra]” (Job 26:13). Pu’a, this is Miriam, as she would make a comforting sound [po’a] to the woman, and the child would emerge. Alternatively, Pu’a, as she would cry [po’a] and weep over her brother Moses who was cast into the Nile, as it is stated: “His sister stood at a distance” (Exodus 2:4). Alternatively, Pu’a, as she revealed [hofia] the actions of her brother. Alternatively, as she stood boldly [pa’at] before Pharaoh and said to him: ‘Woe to you on the Day of Judgment.’

It is taught: A man is called by three names; one that his father and his mother called him, one that others called him, and one that he is called in the book of his lineage.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

Don Yitzchak Abarbanel (ad loc) explains that midwifery consisted of a pair, with each midwife possessing a unique and complementary skill.

He explains that 'Shifra' and 'Puah' were not proper names but rather were terms that denoted these specific skillsets (similar to Chazal).

והנה המילדות א"א שנאמר שהיו שתים בלבד כי איך יספיקו שתי נשים לעם כבד ועצום כבני ישראל ואין לומר שהיו שתים אלא שרות המילדות כלן כדברי המפרשים כי היה ראוי שיקראם הכתוב שרות המילדות כמו שר המשקים ושר האופים ושר הטבחים גם כי מה הועיל פרעה בתקנתו לדבר זה לשרות ההנה אם לא יצוה כן למשרתות שלהן וגם שלא צוה להן שתצוינה זה למילדו' אשר תחתיהן אלא שהענין כך הוא שהיה מנהג במצרים שהיו באות שתים מילדות לעמוד עם כל אשה שהיתה יולדת והאחת מהן היה עסקה בהוצאת הולד ובשכלולו ולכן נקראת שפרה ע"ש שמשפיר' את הולד. והשנית היה עסקה להחזיק ביולדת ולעוזרה בדברים וקולות ותפלות ולכן נקראת פועה מלשון כיולדה אפעה. ואמר שדבר פרעה למילדות העבריות – ר"ל לכולנה כי לא אמר לשתי המילדו' אלא לפי שלכל המילדו' הרבות ההנה דבר וצוה זה וכלן היו נחלקות לשתי אומניות ההם וזה אמרו ששם האחת שפרה ושם השנית פועה. ולא היו עבריות כי איך יבטח לבו בנשים העבריות שימיתו ולדיהן אבל היו מצריות מילדות את העבריות ר"ל עוזרות אותן ללדת כמ"ש בילדכן את העבריות.

"And behold, the midwives cannot be said to be only two, for how could two women suffice for such a heavy and numerous people as the children of Israel? And one cannot say that there were only two, for the midwives were all in charge, as explained by the commentators, for it would have been fitting for the text to call them the head midwives, like the cupbearer, the baker, and the chief cook. Moreover, what benefit did Pharaoh gain from this decree to speak of the head midwives if he did not command this also for their servants? And he did not command them to kill the children that were under them. Rather, the matter is such that there was a custom in Egypt for two midwives to come to attend to each woman giving birth, one of whom was occupied with delivering the child and assisting it, and therefore she was called Shifra, because she beautifies the birth. The second was responsible for holding the mother and assisting her with words and cries and prayers, and thus she was called Puah, from the language of ‘to help the birthing woman.’

And it is said that Pharaoh spoke to the Hebrew midwives—meaning to all of them—because he did not say to the two midwives, but rather to all the many midwives, that this is what he commanded and all of them were divided into those two professions. This is why it is said that the name of one was Shifra and the name of the second was Puah. And they were not Hebrew women, for how could he trust his heart in Hebrew women that they would kill their children? Rather, they were Egyptian women who assisted the Hebrews, meaning they helped them to give birth, as it is said, ‘when you help the Hebrew women.’"

(There is considerable dispute amongst the commentaries as to if the midwives were Jewish or not.

Don Abarbanel holds that they were not, see Shadal at length)

title: Is ראשית really in construct?
content:
# Is ראשית really in construct? ## Frage

There are those who translate בראשית (from Gen 1:1) as "In the beginning of...", saying that ראשית must be in construct form (smikhut). Perhaps most famously, Rashi writes:

שֶׁאֵין לְךָ רֵאשִׁית בַּמִּקְרָא שֶׁאֵינוֹ דָבוּק לַתֵּבָה שֶׁלְּאַחֲרָיו

Because, wherever the word ראשית occurs in Scripture, it is in the construct state

However, this seems not to be true. Ibn Ezra points out:

ויש אומרים כי בראשית לעולם סמוך והטעם בראשית הערב או הלילה או החשך והנה שכחו וירא ראשית לו

Other scholars maintain that the word bereshit is always in the construct and its meaning in our verse is: “In the beginning of the evening, or of the night, or of the darkness.” However, they have overlooked And he chose a first part (reshit) for himself (Deuteronomy 33:21).

I can add Lev 2:12 (קרבן ראשית תקריבו אתם לה׳), Is 46:10 (מגיד מראשית אחרית), Ps 105:36 (ראשית לכל־אונם), and Neh 12:44 (על־הנשכות לאוצרות לתרומות לראשית ולמעשרות), all of which (apparently) have ראשית in absolute form, not construct form. I can add some examples of אחרית, which I imagine would be a similar pattern to ראשית: Jer 29:11 (לתת לכם אחרית ותקוה), Ps 37:37 (כי־אחרית לאיש שלום), Prov 23:18 (כי אם־יש אחרית), Prov 24:14 (ויש אחרית), Prov 24:20 (כי לא־תהיה אחרית לרע).

Is there anyone who defends Rashi (and those who agree) and explains all of these examples as actually being in construct? I'd rather not have to ask about each example individually, so if there is one place that discusses all (or many) of these examples, that'd be great.

title: How many lashes do false witnesses receive?
content:
# How many lashes do false witnesses receive? ## Frage

If two witnesses claim that a person is liable to receive lashes, and their testimony is found to be false, do they receive the amount of lashes that that person would have received, i.e. only the amount that he would be able to handle, or do they receive as many lashes as they themselves can handle?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

Rambam (Edut, 18) says they receive only as many lashes as they can handle:

וְאִם הֵעִידוּ בְּמַלְקוֹת לוֹקֶה כָּל אֶחָד מֵהֶן כִּשְׁאָר מְחֻיְּבֵי מַלְקוֹת. וְאוֹמְדִין כֹּחוֹ וּמַלְקִין אוֹתוֹ.‏

If they testified falsely with regard to a transgression punishable by lashes, each one of them is lashed as are all those obligated to be lashed. We estimate their capacity to bear the lashes and they are lashed.

title: Rambam’s ancient writing spilled on by coffee
content:
# Rambam’s ancient writing spilled on by coffee ## Frage

I heard a beautiful story of a Rabbi, who after being successful in business, decided to try to use his wealth to put together a research team to come up with a definitive edition of the Rambam's works, with resolutions to various competing "versions".

The business purchased an old original writing of the Rambam, and were privileged to be the first to study the text in order to resolve a girsa issue. He was so pleased with their purchase, he arranged that they laid it out one day for the whole company to come and take a look, and be one-on-one with an original writing of the Rambam.

One of the men in the company took his turn, walked in with his coffee, and accidentally spilled it all over the original writing and ruined it. He was so ashamed of himself, but without delay the Rabbi put his arms around him, apologized that his coffee spilled and brought him another one, showing how much he cared for others and didn’t want him to be embarrassed.

Does anyone know where this story is quoted and what the name of the Rabbi is?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 10)

The story is told that it was Rabbi Shabsel Frankel, of the famous Rambam-edition.

Refer to here

It happened after 1975. He found the manuscript in a Egyptian museum.

title: Rambam's endorsement of the Aleppo Codex
content:
# Rambam's endorsement of the Aleppo Codex ## Frage

The wiki article on the Aleppo Codex (here) suggests that the Rambam endorsed its text: "[Rambam] described it as a text trusted by all Jewish scholars". However, following some of the references in the wiki it's unclear where he wrote this or what he specifically said about it.

Appreciate if someone can find a source. Thanks

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 6)

The source is Mishneh Torah, Sefer Ahava, Hilchos Tefilin, Mezuzah, and Sefer Torah, 8:4 (first paragraph):

וּלְפִי שֶׁרָאִיתִי שִׁבּוּשׁ גָּדוֹל בְּכָל הַסְּפָרִים שֶׁרָאִיתִי בִּדְבָרִים אֵלּוּ. וְכֵן בַּעֲלֵי הַמָּסֹרֶת שֶׁכּוֹתְבִין וּמְחַבְּרִין לְהוֹדִיעַ הַפְּתוּחוֹת וְהַסְּתוּמוֹת נֶחְלָקִים בִּדְבָרִים אֵלּוּ בְּמַחֲלֹקֶת הַסְּפָרִים שֶׁסּוֹמְכִין עֲלֵיהֶם. רָאִיתִי לִכְתֹּב הֵנָּה כָּל פָּרָשִׁיּוֹת הַתּוֹרָה הַסְּתוּמוֹת וְהַפְּתוּחוֹת וְצוּרַת הַשִּׁירוֹת כְּדֵי לְתַקֵּן עֲלֵיהֶם כָּל הַסְּפָרִים וּלְהַגִּיהַּ מֵהֶם. וְסֵפֶר שֶׁסָּמַכְנוּ עָלָיו בִּדְבָרִים אֵלּוּ הוּא הַסֵּפֶר הַיָּדוּעַ בְּמִצְרַיִם שֶׁהוּא כּוֹלֵל אַרְבָּעָה וְעֶשְׂרִים סְפָרִים שֶׁהָיָה בִּירוּשָׁלַיִם מִכַּמָּה שָׁנִים לְהַגִּיהַּ מִמֶּנּוּ הַסְּפָרִים וְעָלָיו הָיוּ הַכּל סוֹמְכִין לְפִי שֶׁהִגִּיהוֹ בֶּן אָשֵׁר וְדִקְדֵּק בּוֹ שָׁנִים הַרְבֵּה וְהִגִּיהוֹ פְּעָמִים רַבּוֹת כְּמוֹ שֶׁהֶעְתִּיקוּ וְעָלָיו סָמַכְתִּי בְּסֵפֶר הַתּוֹרָה שֶׁכָּתַבְתִּי כְּהִלְכָתוֹ:

Because I saw serious errors in these matters in all of the scrolls that I have seen, while authorities on the Massorah differ ... I deemed it fit to write here a list of the sections which are closed and which are open, and also the forms of the songs [of the Bible], so that all scrolls can be corrected from, and compared with, them. The book which I relied upon to check the scrolls is the well-known codex in Egypt which contains the twenty-four books [of the Bible] and that had been in Jerusalem for several years, and upon which all relied, because it was proofread by Ben Asher, who worked on it carefully for many years and examined it again whenever it was being copied. This codex was the text upon which I relied in the Scroll of the Torah that I myself wrote according to the halacha.

title: Eradication of Free Will under a functioning Biblical legal system or Talmudic education
content:
# Eradication of Free Will under a functioning Biblical legal system or Talmudic education ## Frage

It is frequently argued that the lack of direct Heavenly intervention in the Creation was designed to allow for a free "pressure-free" choice between good and bad. E.g. when a person breaks Shabbos, eats non-Kosher food, or has illicit relations, no immediate and direct Godly retribution is observed, because otherwise, free will would be revoked, a person would turn into a puppet, and the idea of Heavenly reward and punishment would be invalidated.

On the other hand, God explicitly commands us, humans, to establish a system of courts and police with tight surveillance and harsh and dreadful punishments, e.g. (Deut 17):

"And the man that will act presumptuously, and will not hearken to the priest that stands to minister there before thy God, or to the judge, that man shall die: and thou shalt put away the evil from Yisra᾽el.
And all the people shall hear, and fear, and do no more presumptuously."

In other words, a powerful and properly functioning legal system that enforces Biblical laws represents the opposite of the cultivation of personal free will.

The Talmud advocates for a similar approach in educating children about Torah and Mitzvot, emphasizing corporal punishment as a means to instill a deep-rooted aversion to sin through learned behavior.

How do our sources deal with this contradiction?

N.B. I understand that historically, the idea of free will was developed in the times when Jewish Sanhedrins ceased to exist under Roman rule, and Jewish transgressors were left to the "Heavenly court". I would only like to see if any pro-free-will commentators noticed this contradiction.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

This is an attempt to answer based on my understanding (and as I can tell from the comments, the understanding of other as well)

The concept of free choice means that it is a person has the freedom to choose his actions and is not forced by anyone to choose one way or the other.

Having a court system that imposes death penalties, lashes or fines can act as deterrences but they do not force someone to act a certain way.

On a side note, just to address some of the points made in by the OP

  • the sifrei mussar say that the reason Hashem doesn't punish immediately at time of transgression is to give the transgression time and ability to repent (sources to follow)
  • most transgressions do not carry death penalties, and no lashes exist when one does not observe מצוות עשה. Even when punishments can be given by bais din, one needs witnesses and warnings. This leaves ample room to not observe mitzvoth without the fear of punishment.
### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

I'm not sure how to source this answer; it is the accumulation of a lot of learning but if anything specific I say strikes you, feel free to request a source.

Hashem balances every aspect of life so that we should have free will. For example, Hashem creates it that the yeitzer hara is more attracted to the forbidden, and finds it harder to do good that is expected vs. good "that comes from the heart". This contradicts what we might think, that forbidding something makes it harder for people to choose, or demanding something makes it easier for them.

Another way Hashem ensures free will is by equalizing pleasure. If only good things "tasted good", we would have no trouble being good and avoiding evil. However, it is not like that, and as above, sometimes the forbidden tastes better!

I don't think we need to have a very analytical answer as to how Hashem ensures free will. His ways are too numerous and holistic for us to fathom, not that we can fathom His vast thoughts in general!

I will note though that the Lubavitcher Rebbe makes a very related point - we are living in a time where there is very little "pressure" to do the right thing. This is unprecedented in Jewish History, whether it be that we were on the Land seeing open miracles, or living in Ghettoes where being religious was the ticket to good business and shidduchim for our children, there has, until today, always been something detracting from our good deeds being "lishma".

The whole of history has been a gradual "letting go" of our hand from Hashem, letting us learn to crawl and then walk and seeing how we can behave "by ourself", to get a true measure of our goodness through giving us "truer and truer" free will.

We can trace this from the point of the Megilla, that Hashem's name is not mentioned, and all miracles are "hidden", so as not to provide "supernatural pressure" on us to be good. This state of affairs was so lofty and beneficial, we are described as "only then" having truly accepted the Torah, due to our great response to those challenges.

We can even trace it further back still, and there are sichot that we were initially given a chance to play around with our freedom before the flood, and look what we did. After that, we were more restrained in our freedom by witnessing great leaders, miracles etc. The goal was to refine us internally, with the end result that we should have our hands "let go" again towards the end of history, and we will see that indeed, we have changed and become good deep down.

tl;dr So, this answer is basically saying that no, it is not a contradiction, it does indeed affect our free will. However, Hashem has ways of balancing that out, and even if not, there is a purpose to our free will being more restrained at certain times, and more "truly free" at other times.

title: Per Rashi in Genesis, who were the Nefilim?
content:
# Per Rashi in Genesis, who were the Nefilim? ## Frage

The Torah states (Genesis 6:4):

הַנְּפִלִ֞ים הָי֣וּ בָאָ֘רֶץ֮ בַּיָּמִ֣ים הָהֵם֒ וְגַ֣ם אַֽחֲרֵי־כֵ֗ן אֲשֶׁ֨ר יָבֹ֜אוּ בְּנֵ֤י הָֽאֱלֹהִים֙ אֶל־בְּנ֣וֹת הָֽאָדָ֔ם וְיָלְד֖וּ לָהֶ֑ם הֵ֧מָּה הַגִּבֹּרִ֛ים אֲשׁר מֵעוֹלָ֖ם אַנְשֵׁ֥י הַשֵּֽׁם׃ {פ} It was then, and later too, that the Nephilim appeared on earth—when divine beings cohabited with the human women, who bore them offspring. Such were the heroes of old, the men of renown.

Rashi - הנפלים. עַל שֵׁם שֶׁנָּפְלוּ וְהִפִּילוּ אֶת הָעוֹלָם, וּבְלָשׁוֹן עִבְרִית לְשׁוֹן עֲנָקִים הוּא: THE GIANTS — Thy were called נפילים because they fell (נפלו) and caused the downfall of (הפילו) the world (Genesis Rabbah 26:7).

Are these two different interpretations? Let's focus on the first one.

if we accept the premise that Rashi holds that these Nefilim were prior-angels who fell from heaven. (see further) several questions emerge.

Rashi Bamidbar 13:

הנפילים. עֲנָקִים, מִבְּנֵי שַׁמְחָזַאי וַעֲזָאֵל שֶׁנָּפְלוּ מִן הַשָּׁמַיִם בִּימֵי דּוֹר אֱנוֹשׁ the giants: Heb. נְפִילִים, giants, descended from Shamhazai (Nidah 61a) and Azael (Yoma 67b), who fell (שֶׁנָּפְלוּ) from heaven in the generation of Enosh.

So Rashi in numbers is telling us that the Nefilim spotted by the spies were descendants of fallen angels. Thus, again, it may be fair to say that when Nefilim are mentioned for the very first time in Genesis without the word "sons," it is a reference to those original fallen angels.

Then Rashi in Genesis explains the next part of the verse which follows the phrase 'who bore them offspring' ("such were ... men of renown") - presumably he will 1) elaborate on how/why the offspring of the fallen angels were men of renown or 2) further identify the fallen angels as to how/why they were men of renown ... but instead:

אנשי השם. אוֹתָן שֶׁנִּקְּבוּ בְשֵׁמוֹת עִירָד מְחוּיָאֵל מְתוּשָׁאֵל שֶׁנִּקְּבוּ עַל שֵׁם אָבְדָּן, שֶׁנִּמֹּחוּ וְהֻתְּשׁוּ.אנשי שם MEN OF RENOWN (literally, men of name) — Men who bore distinctive names: עירד, מחויאל, מתושאל being so named because these names have reference to their destruction, for they were wiped out and torn out from the world (מחוי-אל would signify “wiped-out-by-God”, מתושאל “Torn-out-by-God).

quite the non-sequitur ... Rashi suddenly describes a non-fallen angel paternal set - sons of Cain.

****** these men however descended from the human - Kayin. There are no fallen angels in their genetics/DNA/paternity tests nor are these men the original fallen angels?!!**

By way of example, the Beer Basadeh rejects the Mizrachi and Nachalot Yaakov and states that per Rashi and Zohar, Nefilim here in Genesis, is a reference to the original angels cast out of heaven.

So how then did we get to a discussion regarding Cain's children?

  1. Is rashi rejecting the premise that the genesis Nefilim were fallen angels a la his comment in numbers? Is he instead claiming that they were humans of Cain's paternal line and that they fell spiritually and caused others to fall?
  2. Does Rashi agree the Nefilim are fallen angels but then interprets bnei elohim as a different set - from Kain?
  3. or could the genes of the fallen angels be manifest in Cain's line through maternal descent? There is a fascinating sforno on numbers 13:33

בני ענק. מצד האב: בני ענק, descended paternally from giants מן הנפילים. מצד האם: descended maternally from Nefillim

title: When did Sichon's Battle with the Moabites Take Place?
content:
# When did Sichon's Battle with the Moabites Take Place? ## Frage

So the Jews fought Sichon in their last year or so in the desert; Bamidbar 21:26 then tells us that the territory they took "had belonged to Moab, but Sichon battled a previous [or "the first"] king of Moab and took it", and there's a famous poem about that battle.

Of course the Midrash says those "poets" were a young cursor-apprentice Bilaam and his father (Be'or & Son Hexes Inc.).

Do any sources give any chronologies as to when this happened -- how many years before the Jews arrived?

Things to consider:

  • It's a previous king of Moab, but the same Sichon. So it happened less-than-one-Sichon-lifespan ago. (Of course, sources differ on his lifespan...)

  • Bilaam's donkey says she's been around "since when you were", either when he first learned to ride, or when he first got into the cursing business; a donkey's lifespan is 30-ish years ... so if we follow the Midrash that Bilaam was one of the "bards", that would indicate it was no more than 30 years prior.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Rabbi Aryeh Kaplan zt"l never ceases to amaze me. In The Living Torah, he says Sefer HaYashar writes it was four years prior.

Thank you JoelK for finding the source in Sefer HaYashar:

ויהי בשנת שלושים ושש שנה לצאת בני ישראל ממצרים ויער ה' את סיחון מלך האמורי ויערוך מלחמה ויצא להלחם את בני מואב

In the thirty-sixth year since the Jews left Egypt, G-d stirred up Sichon, King of the Emori, and he waged war, going to attack the Moabites.

That would be consistent with a "young-Bilaam" approach. In fact, that same page of Sefar HaYashar splits the difference between the "young-Bilaam" midrashim, and those about Bilaam advising Pharaoh to drown the firstborn. Sefer HaYashar identifies Be'or as son of Yanis, son of Bilaam-the-advisor-of-Pharaoh. So the advising-Pharaoh Bilaam was the great-grandfather and namesake of the cursing-Jews Bilaam!

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

B"H

"a donkey's lifespan is 30-ish years ."

This donkey was created during the six days of creation and lived for thousands of years (pirkei avos chapter 5).

It would have lived forever had the angel not killed it (Rashi parshas balak)

Gemara sotah says that Bilaam was part of the plot to pharaoh to drown the newborn males, which was about 120 years prior.

So it could have been any time

title: "God does" vs "God tells Moses to do"
content:
# "God does" vs "God tells Moses to do" ## Frage

In the Torah, God frequently makes miracles happen either by doing them Himself, or by telling Moses to start them. Examples of the latter are telling Moses to throw a piece of wood in the water to make it drinkable, to strike a rock or talk to a rock to make water come out, to lift up his arm to make the sea split or make Amalek lose, etc. Also, God-commanded gestures by Aaron started many of the ten plagues upon Egypt.

What is the reason for the two different approaches? Do the commentators cover that point?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Bava Metzia 86b

אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר רַב: כׇּל מַה שֶּׁעָשָׂה אַבְרָהָם לְמַלְאֲכֵי הַשָּׁרֵת בְּעַצְמוֹ – עָשָׂה הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא לְבָנָיו בְּעַצְמוֹ. וְכׇל מַה שֶּׁעָשָׂה אַבְרָהָם עַל יְדֵי שָׁלִיחַ – עָשָׂה הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא לְבָנָיו עַל יְדֵי שָׁלִיחַ. ״וְאֶל הַבָּקָר רָץ אַבְרָהָם״, ״וְרוּחַ נָסַע מֵאֵת ה׳״. ״וַיִּקַּח חֶמְאָה וְחָלָב״, ״הִנְנִי מַמְטִיר לָכֶם לֶחֶם מִן הַשָּׁמָיִם״. ״וְהוּא עֹמֵד עֲלֵיהֶם תַּחַת הָעֵץ״, ״הִנְנִי עֹמֵד לְפָנֶיךָ שָּׁם עַל הַצּוּר [וְגוֹ׳]״. ״וְאַבְרָהָם הֹלֵךְ עִמָּם לְשַׁלְּחָם״, ״וַה׳ הֹלֵךְ לִפְנֵיהֶם יוֹמָם״.

Rav Yehuda says that Rav says: Every action that Abraham performed himself for the ministering angels, the Holy One, Blessed be He, performed Himself for Abraham’s descendants. And every action that Abraham performed through a messenger, the Holy One, Blessed be He, likewise performed for his descendants through a messenger. The Gemara elaborates: With regard to Abraham, the verse states: “And Abraham ran to the herd” (Genesis 18:7), bringing the meat himself, and in reference to God’s actions for Abraham’s descendants the verse states: “And there went forth a wind from the Lord, and brought across quails from the sea” (Numbers 11:31), that God brought meat to them. In reference to Abraham, the verse states: “And he took curd and milk” (Genesis 18:8), and God says to the Jewish people: “Behold, I will cause to rain bread from heaven for you” (Exodus 16:4), which shows that God gave food to the Jewish people. With regard to Abraham, the verse states: “And he stood by them under the tree, and they ate” (Genesis 18:8), and in reference to God, the verse states: “Behold, I will stand before you there upon the rock in Horeb; and you shall strike the rock, and there shall come water out of it” (Exodus 17:6). In the case of Abraham it is written: “And Abraham went with them to bring them on the way” (Genesis 18:16), and the verse states: “And the Lord went before them by day” (Exodus 13:21). By contrast, Abraham performed certain actions through an agent. He said: “Let now a little water be fetched” (Genesis 18:4), and correspondingly the verse states in reference to Moses, God’s messenger: “And you shall strike the rock, and there shall come water out of it, that the people may drink” (Exodus 17:6).

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

Rabbi Pinchas Horowitz, the Baal Haflaah, explains in the Haggadah by the phrase "I and not an angel", that there are two redemptions - outer and inner. The outer redemption was the physical freedom from slavery, and this was given to Moshe. The inner redemption was the redemption from idol worship; Hashem Himself had to work on the inside of the Neshamot of Benei Yisrael to redeem them from this.

This is a general theme - sparks can only actually be rescued by Hashem Himself. We do the work, but the actual extracting of the spark from the klipa is beyond our power and is only in the power of the One Who is above, and the Master of Good and Evil, i.e. the "Ba'al HaRatzon" - Hashem Himself.

title: Must I follow suit and stand for Kiddush?
content:
# Must I follow suit and stand for Kiddush? ## Frage

There are different customs whether to stand or sit during Kiddush. Even those who stand for all/part of Friday Night Kiddush, many sit for the Shabbos Day Kiddush.

I have observed a common trend to imitate the person making Kiddush. People who would stand when they make Kiddush will sit when the mekadesh is sitting; people who usually sit will stand when the mekadesh is standing.

The concept of sitting when the mekadesh is sitting, I believe is based on Tosafos (Berachos 43), that a form of kevius is necessary for listeners to fulfil their obligation through the public recital of the mekadesh. This idea is mentioned by Mishnah Berurah (271:46):

ויותר טוב לישב – דבכי האי גוונא מקרי טפי קידוש במקום סעודה כיון שיושב במקום סעודתו בעת הקידוש. וכן הסכים בבאור הגר״א ומטעם אחר, דכיון שאחד פוטר חברו בעינן קביעות שיקבעו יחד ובישיבה מקרי קביעות וכנ״ל בסימן קס״ז ולפי דבריו גם השומעים צריכין לישב וטוב ליזהר בזה לכתחלה

However, I could not find any real source for standing because the mekadesh is standing. The closest I could find to a 'source' was this ruling on shulchanaruchharav.com written by a [unknown to me!] Rabbi Yaakov Goldstein:

Whether the listeners are to stand or sit during Kiddush follows the same ruling as the person making Kiddush. Practically, the custom is to stand if the person making Kiddush is standing, although if he is sitting, one can choose to stand or sit.

Although most rulings on this site cite sources in the footnotes, this specific ruling is unsourced.

Does this custom/ruling have any halachic basis?

I'll accept an answer that either finds a primary source for this custom, or a halachic source disproving this custom.

This is not a duplicate of this question, which focuses on the general obligation to stand or sit during Kiddush. I am specifically looking for source of custom to stand when mekadesh is standing.
