title: Why was the snake jealous and wanted to marry Chava?
content:
# Why was the snake jealous and wanted to marry Chava? ## Frage

As we know from midrash Bereshit Rabba 18:6 and Rashi to 3:1, the snake was the only animal that could talk, and became jealous when it saw Adam and Chava having relations in the garden. The snake wanted to marry Chava. One lady asked me a while ago: "Every animal in the Garden had a wife except for Adam prior to creation of Chava. Why did the snake additionally want to marry Chava?"

Alternatively, as a the parallel question asks, if the Snake was female and had a husband, why did it want to marry Adam? What is the meaning of this Midrash about Eve in the Garden?

One can certainly explain the story using the words of Midrash haGadol 3:1 about angel S-mael, that it was not a natural occurrence. However, the story in Bereshit does not have details of midrashim, written many years later as ethical teachings, not the documentary of what actually occurred. If the snake could really have relations with Chava, why would Adam let her be alone? Is it possible to explain the story in a way that is straight and reasonable?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

I don't know your source for suggesting that the snake was specifically jealous of Chava, but the Gemara in Sanhedrin 59b notes expressly that its jealousy was of Adam for the following reason:

מיתיבי היה ר' יהודה בן תימא אומר אדם הראשון מיסב בגן עדן היה והיו מלאכי השרת צולין לו בשר ומסננין לו יין הציץ בו נחש וראה בכבודו ונתקנא בו התם בבשר היורד מן השמים

The Gemara raises an objection from a baraita to the assertion that eating meat was prohibited to Adam: Rabbi Yehuda ben Teima would say: Adam, the first man, would dine in the Garden of Eden, and the ministering angels would roast meat for him and strain wine for him. The snake glanced at him and saw his glory, and was jealous of him, and for that reason the snake incited him to sin and caused his banishment from the Garden. According to this, evidently Adam would eat meat. The Gemara answers: There the reference is to meat that descended from heaven, which was created by a miracle and was not the meat of animals at all. (William Davidson translation and notation)

### ✅ Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

Netziv writes on Bereshis 3:1

And the serpent was more cunning, etc.: Rashi explained in the name of Midrash Rabbah that it was jealous of them, in that it saw them copulating together and desired her. But this is a wonder! As behold, every creature only desires its species, as it is found in Tractate Bava Metzia 91b: "Its species - it is drawn after its species." And behold the serpent was not lacking its female. And if it was on account of their having intercourse before the eyes of all, the serpent also did not know shame.

Rather the matter is that it sensed that the clinging of the women to her husband was not like its female to it, which only occurred at the time of arousal for copulation. And that is only by happenstance and preparation for the thing. Which was not the case with the woman, who constantly clung to him: Given that she was the bone of his bones, the clinging was even more than a brother and sister. For they too are one flesh. However they are nevertheless not truly so like the first woman to Adam, who was like a limb to the head. And it was jealous of this.

And behold the matter is understood that the serpent never spoke. For if it had originally spoken but was cursed to be dumb and silent, why is this curse not mentioned? Moreover, speech depends on intelligence, and as per Rashi's explanation of, "and so man became a living soul" Genesis 2:7) - with speech and intelligence. And likewise did Onkelos translate, "With a speaking spirit." Behold man was unique in this virtue. However it was the constellation of the serpent that clothed himself with jealousy and spoke at that time from the throat of the serpent.

As every species from all that was created - even the botanic - has a constellation; and that is the angel that is appointed upon that species to protect it and grow it, so that it not cease from the world. And this is like the Sages, may their memory be blessed, said, "You have no [blade of] grass below without its constellation above striking it and saying to it, 'Grow!'" And the constellation of the serpent was like [the serpent]; as it was jealous of man's clinging to his Creator, may He be blessed. And it is just as we explained in the previous section, that Adam clung so greatly to God, like a portion that always yearns for its source; which is not the case with an angel. It is just separated and it is not clinging and yearning for His light, may He be blessed, except for at the time designated for song and that which is similar. And the angel was jealous about Adam; and the physical serpent about his wife. And [about] that which all of this is not explained in Scripture, the Ramban has already written, in Parashat Bechukotai - and we brought it earlier (Haamek Davar on Bereishit 1:1) - that regarding things that are not grasped by everyone, the Torah only spoke about it by hinting.

title: Why does Kabbalah use the term "olamot" conjugated in the feminine when the Tanakh conjugates it as "olamim" in the masculine?
content:
# Why does Kabbalah use the term "olamot" conjugated in the feminine when the Tanakh conjugates it as "olamim" in the masculine? ## Frage

I'm curious why "olam" would be conjugated in the feminine throughout Kabbalah (as in the "arba'ah olamot") when as far as I know it is a masculine noun and is conjugated with the "olamim" ending in Tanakh. A brief search suggests that olamim refers to worlds (space) and olamot refers to eternities (time), but I haven't found a source to explain or confirm this idea.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

A similar case appears in the Gemara in Chullin 137b:

כי סליק איסי בר היני אשכחיה לר' יוחנן דקא מתני ליה לבריה רחלים אמר ליה אתנייה רחלות א"ל כדכתיב (בראשית לב, טו) רחלים מאתים אמר ליה לשון תורה לעצמה לשון חכמים לעצמן
§ When Isi bar Hini ascended from Babylonia to Eretz Yisrael, Rabbi Yoḥanan found him teaching the mishna to his son. Isi taught that the obligation of the first sheared wool applies only in the case of sheep [reḥelim], the masculine plural form of raḥel, meaning a sheep. Rabbi Yoḥanan said to Isi: You should teach him using the term reḥelot, the feminine plural form. Isi said to him in reply: I teach the mishna in accordance with that which is written: “Two hundred reḥelim” (Genesis 32:15). Rabbi Yoḥanan said to Isi: The language of the Torah is distinct and the language of the Sages is distinct, i.e., these are like two separate languages, and the Sages do not always use the same forms that appear in the Bible. In this case, they use reḥelot rather than reḥelim.

The commentary Ben Yehoyada says that the form that ends with ת implies more connection between the individuals than the one that doesn't (see there for why that is important in the Rabbinic context.) Perhaps the Kabbalists are trying to emphasize the connectedness of the worlds, which is a foundational principle of Chazal's worldview (see Ramchal's introduction to Aggadta.)

The word Olamim in the Bible refers to periods of time. An olam is a long time (sometimes 50 years), and olamim is many periods of time, often eternity (see here). Olamot in the Rabbinic literature refers to spiritual realms.

title: Why mention Balak ben Tzipor?
content:
# Why mention Balak ben Tzipor? ## Frage

In Parashat Balak 22:10 it says,

וַיֹּ֥אמֶר בִּלְעָ֖ם אֶל־הָאֱלֹהִ֑ים בָּלָ֧ק בֶּן־צִפֹּ֛ר מֶ֥לֶךְ מוֹאָ֖ב שָׁלַ֥ח אֵלָֽי׃

Balaam said to God, “Balak son of Zippor, king of Moab, sent me this message:

Many of the commentaries comment and mention why the need to say “King of Moab”, but I haven’t seen anyone mention why he had to say “son of Tzipor”. Just say Balak king of Moab. Any reason why he mentioned it?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

In addition to my comment (I still stand by it :-)) note the approach of the Bnei Yissaschar in his Agra DeKallah who picks up on the specific mention of Tzippor minus the vav - i.e. צפר as opposed to צפור.

He wants to demonstrate that the referencing of ben Tzippor was a backwards way of acknowledging how Bilam superseded the king, as he alone had the power to bring down the Jewish people.

He writes:

וכן האזינה עדי בנו צפ"ר (במדבר כג יח). והנראה דהנה בעסק מעשה הכשפים היה בלק יותר מבלעם (במ"ר פ"כ ז'), כי בלעם היה כוחו בדיבור ובלק במעשה, ובלעם לגודל גבהות לבו רצה להראות שצריך לו מכל וכל, כי אין כח בלק גם במעשה זולתו. על כן אמר חסר ו', כבר ידעת כי ו' מורה על המעשה, וכן האזינה עדי בנו צפ"ר, אמר לו לעגמת נפש שמעשיו אינם חשובים כלום למעשה:

And refer similarly to "Give ear unto me, son of Tzippor" (Bamidbar 23:18) (i.e. also spelt without the vav) which indicates that here in the witchcraft business, Balak was greater than Bilam (see Bamidbar Rabbah 20:7) since Bilam's strength was in speech and Balak's was in action. And Bilam in his great arrogance wanted to show that he was needed more than anyone else, for there is no power of Balak even in the actions of others. Therefore, Tzippor is spelt without the vav, since you already know that vav intimates/teaches about action (and here Balak was not able to show that sense of action), likewise when he said "Give ear unto me, son of Tzippor". He told him angrily that his actions meant nothing in fact

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

Mabye we need to focus on pasuk 22:9, "וַיָּבֹ֥א אֱלֹהִ֖ים אֶל־בִּלְעָ֑ם וַיֹּ֕אמֶר מִ֛י הָאֲנָשִׁ֥ים הָאֵ֖לֶּה עִמָּֽךְ׃, "Hashem came to Bilam and said, “What do these men want of you?”

Rashi quoting Midrash Tanchuma Balak 5 says:

מי האנשים האלה עמך. לְהַטְעוֹתוֹ בָא, אָמַר פְּעָמִים שֶׁאֵין הַכֹּל גָּלוּי לְפָנָיו, אֵין דַּעְתּוֹ שָׁוָה עָלָיו, אַף אֲנִי אֶרְאֶה עֵת שֶׁאוּכַל לְקַלֵּל וְלֹא יָבִין (תנחומא):

"By putting this question Hashem intended to trick Bilam. And indeed Bilam thereupon said: “It seems, then, that there are times when everything is not manifest to Him; His knowledge is not always alike. I will select a time when I can curse and when He will not observe it."

As a side point, the Maskil L'David on Bamidbar 22:9 says:

מי האנשים וכו להטעותו וכו כלומר לנסותו אם יטעה לתלות חסרון בידיעתו ית׳ חלילה והוא טעה ואמר וכו׳ ומה שלא כפר לגמרי לומר שאין גלוי לפניו אלא אמר פעמים לפי שלא היה יכול לכפור לגמרי הואיל והיה נביא וידע בודאי מזה שהוא יתב׳ מגיד מראשית אחרית.

"...And what he did not completely deny by saying that it is not revealed before Him, but said sometimes, because he could not completely deny it since he was a prophet and knew for certain that Hashem reveals the end from the beginning." Meaning that its not that Bilam completely denied that Hashem knows everything, but its that sometimes he is not aware.

So based on Rashi we can say that mabye Bilam thinks that Chas Veshalom Hashem doesn't always know everything, so he doesn't know that Balak is "ben tzipor," meaning someone who uses birds for his magic speacil powers (as mentioned by the Or Hachaim on 22:2 quoting the Zohar Hakadosh 3:184b). Since Hashem is not always aware (according to what Bilam thinks), Bilam needs to tell Hashem of the speacil powers that Balak posseses, which gives importance and a claim/good reason to go and curse Bnei Yisrael. Thats why he is also very detailed in his answer, as if Hashem does not know who these people are and what is going on.

Hope this helps :)

### ✅ Antwort 3 (Score: 1)

Baruch Hashem I was directed to an answer that I believe answers the question and would like to share with the olam

The question was misleading. Instead of asking why mention Ben Tzipor the question should really be deeper and ask why mention Balak at all? Now this is not my question, it’s brought from Daat Zekenim on this verse whose quotes Bamidbar Rabbah 28:6:

וַיַּרְא בָּלָק, כֵּיוָן שֶׁבָּאוּ שְׁלוּחָיו אֵצֶל בִּלְעָם, אָמַר לוֹ הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא (במדבר כב, ט): מִי הָאֲנָשִׁים, אָמַר לוֹ בִּלְעָם (במדבר כב, י): בָּלָק בֶּן צִפֹּר מֶלֶךְ מוֹאָב שָׁלַח אֵלָי, אָמַר רַבִּי אַבָּא בַּר כַּהֲנָא, זֶה אֶחָד מִשְׁלשָׁה בְּנֵי אָדָם שֶׁבְּדָקָן הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא וּמָצָא קָרוֹן שֶׁל מֵי רַגְלַיִם: קַיִן, חִזְקִיָה וּבִלְעָם. קַיִּן בְּשָׁעָה שֶׁאָמַר לוֹ הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא (בראשית ד, ט): אֵי הֶבֶל אָחִיךָ, בִּקֵּשׁ לְהַטְעוֹת כִּבְיָכוֹל, הָיָה צָרִיךְ לוֹמַר רִבּוֹנוֹ שֶׁל עוֹלָם הַנִּסְתָּרוֹת וְהַנִּגְלוֹת לְפָנֶיךָ גְּלוּיוֹת, וְאַתָּה שׁוֹאֲלֵנִי בִּשְׁבִיל אָחִי, אֶלָּא אָמַר לוֹ (בראשית ד, ט): לֹא יָדַעְתִּי הַשֹּׁמֵר אָחִי אָנֹכִי, אָמַר לוֹ הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא חַיֶּיךָ כָּךְ דִּבַּרְתָּ (בראשית ד, י): קוֹל דְּמֵי אָחִיךָ צֹעֲקִים. חִזְקִיָּה כְּשֶׁעָמַד מֵחָלְיוֹ שָׁלַח לוֹ מְרֹדַךְ בַּלְאֲדָן דּוֹרוֹן, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר (ישעיה לט, א): בָּעֵת הַהִיא שָׁלַח מְרֹדַךְ בַּלְאֲדָן בָּא יְשַׁעְיָה אָמַר לוֹ (ישעיה לט, ג): מָה אָמְרוּ הָאֲנָשִׁים הָאֵלֶּה וּמֵאַיִן יָבֹאוּ אֵלֶיךָ, הָיָה צָרִיךְ לוֹמַר אַתְּ נָבִיא שֶׁל מָקוֹם וְלִי אַתְּ שׁוֹאֵל, אֶלָּא הִתְחִיל מִתְגָּאֶה וְאָמַר (ישעיה לט, ג): מֵאֶרֶץ רְחוֹקָה בָּאוּ אֵלַי מִבָּבֶל, אָמַר לוֹ יְשַׁעְיָה הוֹאִיל וְכָךְ אָמַרְתָּ (ישעיה לט, ו ז): הִנֵּה יָמִים בָּאִים וְנִשָֹּׂא [את] כָּל אֲשֶׁר בְּבֵיתֶךָ, וּמִבָּנֶיךָ אֲשֶׁר יֵצְאוּ מִמְךָ, וְהָיוּ סָרִיסִים בְּהֵיכַל מֶלֶךְ בָּבֶל. וְכֵן בִּלְעָם הָרָשָׁע בְּשָׁעָה שֶׁשָּׁלַח בָּלָק אֶצְלוֹ, אָמַר לוֹ הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא: מִי הָאֲנָשִׁים הָאֵלֶּה עִמָּךְ, הָיָה צָרִיךְ לוֹמַר רִבּוֹנוֹ שֶׁל עוֹלָם הַכֹּל גָּלוּי לְפָנֶיךָ וְאֵין כָּל דָּבָר נֶעֱלָם מִמֶּךָּ וְלִי אַתְּ שׁוֹאֵל, אֶלָּא אָמַר לוֹ: בָּלָק בֶּן צִפֹּר מֶלֶךְ מוֹאָב שָׁלַח אֵלָי. אָמַר הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא הוֹאִיל וְכָךְ אַתָּה מְדַבֵּר (במדבר כב, יב): לֹא תָאֹר אֶת הָעָם. אָמַר הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא רָשָׁע שֶׁבָּעוֹלָם, כְּתִיב עַל יִשְׂרָאֵל (זכריה ב, יב): כִּי הַנֹּגֵעַ בָּכֶם כְּנֹגֵעַ בְּבָבַת עֵינוֹ, וְאַתָּה הוֹלֵךְ לִגַּע בָּהֶם וּלְקַלְּלָם, תֵּצֵא עֵינוֹ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר (במדבר כד, ג): שְׂתֻם הָעָיִן, לְקַיֵּם כָּל הַנֹּגֵעַ בָּהֶם כְּנֹגֵעַ בְּבָבַת עֵינוֹ.

“Balak…saw” – when his emissaries came to Bilam, the Holy One blessed be He said to him: “Who are [these] men…?” (Numbers 22:9). Bilam said to Him: “Balak son of Tzipor, king of Moav, sent to me” (Numbers 22:10). Rabbi Abba bar Kahana said: This is one of three people whom the Holy One blessed be He examined but found them to be a jug of urine. They are Cain, Hezekiah, and Bilam. Cain, when the Holy One blessed be He said to him: ‘Where is your brother Abel?’ he sought, as it were, to mislead. He should have said: ‘Master of the universe, the concealed and the revealed are revealed before You, and You are asking me regarding my brother?’ Instead, he said to Him: “I do not know; am I my brother’s keeper?” (Genesis 4:9). The Holy One blessed be He said to him: ‘This is how you speak? “The voice of your brother's blood cries out to Me from the ground. [Now, you are cursed…]”’ (Genesis 4:10–11). Hezekiah, when he recovered from his illness, Merodakh Baladan sent him a gift, as it is stated: “At that time, Merodakh Baladan…sent [scrolls and a gift to Hezekiah]” (Isaiah 39:1). Isaiah came and said to him: “What did those men say, and from where did they come to you?” (Isaiah 39:3). He [Hezekiah] should have said to him: ‘You are a prophet of the Omnipresent, and you are asking me?’ Instead, he began boasting: “They came to me from a distant land, from Babylonia” (Isaiah 39:3). Isaiah said to him: ‘Since that is what you said: “Behold, days are coming and everything that is in your house…will be carried [to Babylonia]…From your sons, who will descend from you…they will be officials in the palace of the king of Babylon”’ (Isaiah 39:6–7). Likewise, the wicked Bilam, when Balak sent to him, the Holy One blessed be He said to him: “Who are these men with you?” (Numbers 22:9), he should have said: ‘Master of the universe, everything is revealed before You and nothing is obscured from You, and You are asking me?’ Instead he said to him: “Balak son of Tzipor, king of Moav, sent to me.” The Holy One blessed be He said to him: ‘Since that is how you speak, “do not curse the people” (Numbers 22:12). The Holy One blessed be He said: ‘Wicked one of the world, it is written in Israel’s regard: “For one who touches you, touches the pupil of his eye” (Zechariah 2:12), and you go to accost them and curse them? Let his eye be removed, as it is stated: “One with an open eye” (Numbers 24:3), to realize: “For one who touches you, touches the pupil of his eye.”’

From here was can see that Bilam having mentioned anything to Hashem was a mistake and was “the reason” why Hashem didn’t let him curse the Jewish people. So now that we know that he didn’t mention Balak Ben Tzipor as part of a claim (as he did when he mentions “King of Moab” as Aderet Eliyahu explains that it was his hava mina that Hashem would accept his claim, if not he would not have asked), we need to understand why mention it at all? So really you can ask the same question on Cain and Adam Harishon and Chizkiyahu and say that they made a mistake and didn’t answer Hashem properly. But in this specific case we are given a glimpse of answer by taking what @Avishai Tebeka has answered and fitting it into this explanation as follows:

Bilam was a prophet and understood the greatness and power of Hashem. But as Rashi quoting Midrash Tanchuma Balak 5 says:

מי האנשים האלה עמך. לְהַטְעוֹתוֹ בָא, אָמַר פְּעָמִים שֶׁאֵין הַכֹּל גָּלוּי לְפָנָיו, אֵין דַּעְתּוֹ שָׁוָה עָלָיו, אַף אֲנִי אֶרְאֶה עֵת שֶׁאוּכַל לְקַלֵּל וְלֹא יָבִין (תנחומא):

Bilam clearly mistakenly believed that there are times where Hashem, Chas veShalom, isn’t aware/doesn’t know and can be taken advantage of. Now in the context of this explanation it is difficult to understand how Bilam used this as a reason to ask Hashem to curse because if he truly believed that there are these times where he can curse without Hashem knowing then why even bring it up to Hashem? Just curse at this moment?! So leaving that aside we can use this to answer our question by saying that Bilam answered Hashem in this way because he believed that sometimes Hashem is not aware and when he was asked “Who are these people” he gave Hashem a genuine answer, and that was exactly his mistake. He should have understood that it’s a rhetorical question because Hashem knows everything. So he answered Hashem Balak Ben Tzipor because he thought that there are times when Hashem does not know certain things and since Hashem asked him this question he wanted to answer accordingly (he didn’t have a hava mina that it’s a rhetorical question because he didn’t believe that Hashem is always all knowing). And he mentioned King of Moab either for this same reason, or more fittingly, as a claim to be able to even ask Hashem to curse the Jewish nation as Aderet Eliyahu explains in his comment

With this we can understand not only why Bilam mentioned Ben Tzipor, but further why he mentioned Balak at all and by looking at Aderet Eliyahu also understanding why he mentioned King of Moab

title: Pronunciation based on grammatical concepts
content:
# Pronunciation based on grammatical concepts ## Frage

There is a grammatical concept as follows, if I'm not mistaken:

If [Aleph, Hei, Yud, Vav] comes at the end of one word, the dot of the first letter in the following word is dropped.

My question is, how does this affect the pronunciation of the second word?

For example:

  1. Pirkei Avot, perek Dalet, paragraph Chaf:
    Is כְתוּבָה pronounced ketuva or chetuva?

  2. Pirkei Avot, perek Hei, paragraph Chet (last word):
    Is כַהֲלָכָה pronounced kahalacha or chahalacha?

I could be very wrong, as I’m still learning. Please correct me if so.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

If one of the six begedkefet letters is written without a dagesh (dot inside the letter), then it is always pronounced as a fricative, rather than as a plosive.

So, in the examples you gave, the kaf appears without a dagesh and is therefore pronounced as a voiceless uvular fricative or voiceless velar fricative (depending on one's tradition) - often transliterated as 'kh' or 'ch'.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

In the specific cases you mention, the Od Yosef Hai siddur (who is very exacting on this) has them both as khaf or chaf (not kaf).

The full rule you are referring to is brought in Em Lamikra Velamasoret (by Rabbi Nissan Sharoni) perek 15. It discusses beged kefet losing its daghesh when coming after an open syllable at the end of the previous word.

He brings there 5 exceptions to this rule:

  • Mapik (pronounced): if the ending letters are a Nach nireh (already implied in the way I worded the original rule).
  • Mafsik (stopped): if there is a ta'am mafsik on the word before the beged kefet, rendering the two words separate.
  • Dahik (pressed): when the previous word ends with a silent he after a patach, seghol, or kamatz, or if the word ends with a he, khaf, or thaf with a kamatz on them, and there is a makaf between that word and the beged kefet word (I believe there are exceptions to this).
  • Atei Merahik (coming from afar): when the previous word is mileil and ends with a he preceded by a seghol or kamatz, or ends with a he, khaf, or thaf with a kamatz, and the beged kefet word has its hat'amah on the first tenuah (slightly different than syllable).
  • Otiot domot (similar letters): the beged kefet word starts with two of the same letter, the first being a prefix.

None of these exceptions occur in the case listed by the OP, as they would be applied in a Mishna. So the letter כ loses the daghesh in both cases.

title: Why is There a Switch in Grammar in Sh'ma?
content:
# Why is There a Switch in Grammar in Sh'ma? ## Frage

The Sh'ma begins with Dvarim 6:4:

:שְׁמַ֖ע יִשְׂרָאֵ֑ל ה׳ אֱלֹהֵ֖ינוּ ה׳ | אֶחָֽד

Hear, O Israel: The Lord is our God; the Lord is one.

Moshe speaks to the nation in the imperative/command form - "Hear"! This form is used to issue a command in the second person — that is, the command is directed at the person being spoken to.

But then the next verse immediately switches grammatical form:

וְאָ֣הַבְתָּ֔ אֵ֖ת ה׳ אֱלֹהֶ֑יךָ בְּכָל־לְבָֽבְךָ֥ וּבְכָל־נַפְשְׁך וּבְכָל־מְאֹדֶֽךָ:

And you shall love the Lord, your God, with all your heart and with all your soul, and with all your means.

Moshe now tells the nation to love God, but it is in the sequential perfect form. The sequential perfect form, true to its name, discusses a sequence of events. Here it can carry the same meaning as the verb before it - command form. Such as in לֵ֤ךְ וְאָֽמַרְתָּ֙ אֶל־עַבְדִּ֣י אֶל־דָּוִ֔ד/Go and say to my servant David (Samuel 2 7:5). And so is this a normal example of Hebrew Grammar (שמע and ואהבת are both commands) or is something else going on here?

Is the fact that the verses discuss different mitzvot - the Mitzva of God's Oneness v. the Mitzva of loving God - a clue?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Yes I believe your suggestion is correct - the switch in grammar has to do with the context of each statement. Let’s break it down:

The first statement that Hashem is our Gd and He is one is stated as a fact. No room to argue or to need to comprehend anything, it just is

Whereas the next verse which commands us to love Gd, even though it’s a commandment and we must do it, you cannot force someone to love something unless they do. Therefore the statement could not have been in the command form because it is something which requires each individual to think about and contemplate to reach this level of love. It’s not something black and white like knowing that Gd is one and can therefore be commanded. This is about emotions and therefore must come from a place of self desire and cannot be commanded upon.

My proof from this comes from Sefer Hamitzvot positive commandments 1, 2 and 3. It is evident from his wording that knowing that Gd exists and that He is one is just a fact that was commanded to us without room for us to think and comprehend. Whereas loving Gd he mentions how we need to contemplate and bring ourselves to understanding etc proving that it’s not something that can be commanded and therefore explains the change in grammar in the verse

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

According to Sefer haChinuch mitzvah 420, the first passuk is acceptance of kingship for the entire Jewish nation, while the rest of the verses speak of other important individual mitzvos listed elsewhere in the Sefer. There are also different halachic requirements to the 1st verse (Shulchan Aruch, Orach Chaim, 61:5-7, Ram"a and Mishna Berura there. For example, one cannot walk when reciting the first verse as a result.

content:
# Bowing during Shmonei Esrei - why only sometimes ## Frage

Why don’t we bow every time we say “Barach Ata” during Shmonei Esrei? Are you allowed to if you wanted to? Is there a specific reason why we only bow at specific brachas? Thanks

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

It is a subject of Shulchan Aruch Orach Chaim 113:1 and Mishna Berurah there. Technically, one can bow at the end of each blessing and in the middle. At the beginning of a blessings it is inappropriate. The reason, so that not to uproot takanat chachamim which will make it appear that each and every praying person is stringent in accordance with his liking, and suspect to being arrogant, who want to show they are stricter than the rest of the tzibur.

title: Reconciling Maimonides' Interpretation of Theodicy in the Book of Job: Eliphaz vs. Elihu
content:
# Reconciling Maimonides' Interpretation of Theodicy in the Book of Job: Eliphaz vs. Elihu ## Frage

A question has been on my mind, and I would appreciate your opinion.

While studying chapter 23 of the third book of the Moreh Nevukhim, Rambam (Maimonides) seems to acknowledge the traditional view of theodicy represented by Eliphaz in the Book of Job (Job 4:7-8), where suffering is seen as a direct retribution for sins:

Remember, I pray thee, who ever perished, being innocent? Or where were the upright cut off? According to what I have seen, those who plow iniquity and sow trouble, reap the same.

However, he also seems to give credit to Elihu's perspective, presented in Job 32-37, which suggests that suffering can be a test or a divine lesson, and that the ways of God are often beyond our understanding. Elihu states in Job 33:14:

For God speaks in one way, and in two, though man does not perceive it

and further in Job 34:10-12, he insists on God's justice:

Therefore, listen to me, you men of understanding: far be it from God to do wickedness, and from the Almighty to commit iniquity. For according to the work of a man, He will repay him, and according to his ways, He will make it befall him. Of a truth, God will not do wickedly, and the Almighty will not pervert justice.

This appears to be a significant nuance compared to Eliphaz's view. Is Maimonides deviating from the Jewish tradition by incorporating Elihu's perspective?

I must admit, I am a bit lost, and most of the commentaries I have seen on this haven't helped. How can Rambam deviate from what he considers the Jewish view of Hashgacha (Divine Providence)?

Thank you for your insights.

title: Would Rabbinic Jews during the second temple have been allowed to marry Sadducees?
content:
# Would Rabbinic Jews during the second temple have been allowed to marry Sadducees? ## Frage

My understanding is that the Sadducees did not believe in resurrection of the dead and disagreed or interpreted the oral tradition very differently than the Pharisees and Rabbinic Jews in the times of Bayit Sheni. At the end of tractate Kiddushin it lists different groups of Jews and indicates which groups are allowed to marry each other. There is no indication there that Sadducees are a group that is forbidden to marry.

My question is, are there any sources in the mishna, midrash halacha, tosefta or talmudim which would indicate whether or not Rabbinic Jews would have been permitted to marry Sadducees (and vice versa) or not?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

The Saducees only existed for a short amount of time, from the middle of the Hasmonean period to the destruction of the temple. They wouldn't be relevant in the time of the Gemara but you might find references to min(im) - heretical sects of Judaism.

The Karites are a sect that is still around today. They also held views different from normative Jews. Like the Saducees, they also deny aspects/authority of the oral law. They claim a connection to the Saducees, though they were separated by about 1000 years.

There is a presumption that they are all Mamzerim (bastards) because over the years, more and more people will be descended from remarried divorcees who did not divorce in a rabbinically approved manner. However, in 1972 R' Ovadia Yosef ruled you can marry a Karite who accepts rabbinic law, which would imply the bastardy really isn't a problem.(Perhaps he held that rabbinic bastardy is only a fence and the Karites aren't held to be d'orita bastards).

In contrast to the Karites, the Saducees wouldn't have enough time to propagate bastards and, since many of them lived and died before the Mishna Rabbis, rabbinic bastardy might not have been codified yet. If you wanted to marry a Saducee, asking around on an individual level would probably suffice to rule out an improper divorce.

title: Why different signs: Nachash vs Tannin?
content:
# Why different signs: Nachash vs Tannin? ## Frage

I would like to understand why in Sefer Shemot YHWH gives Moses the sign of turning his rod into a nachash for the elders of Israel, and later when both Moses and Aaron are in front of Pharoah, Aaron's rod is turned into a tannin? I guess my question is why is the nachash for Israel and the tannin for Egypt?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

The Chibbah Yeteira answers that in the wilderness (where Hashem spoke to Moshe) it turned to a snake because the wilderness is a “place of snakes”, whereas in Egypt it turned to a Tanin because Egypt is a “place of Taninim”

Rabbeinu Bachya says that a Nachash and Tanin are the same thing, and the proof is precisely that both words are used

### Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

Great question! Your question is answered by both Ramban and Chizkuni on the relevant verses; I’ve quoted them below for reference:

Exodus 4:3

וַיֹּ֙אמֶר֙ הַשְׁלִיכֵ֣הוּ אַ֔רְצָה וַיַּשְׁלִכֵ֥הוּ אַ֖רְצָה וַיְהִ֣י לְנָחָ֑שׁ וַיָּ֥נׇס מֹשֶׁ֖ה מִפָּנָֽיו׃

[God] said, “Cast it on the ground.” He cast it on the ground and it became a snake; and Moses recoiled from it.

Ramban on this verse says

AND HE SAID: CAST IT ON THE GROUND. AND HE CAST IT ON THE GROUND. I do not understand why G-d performed the signs before Moses. Moses believed that it is the Holy One, blessed be He, Who speaks with him, and it would have been fitting for Him to say, “The staff that is in your hand you shall cast on the ground before them, and it shall become a serpent,” and the same also with respect to the second sign, [i.e., his hand becoming leprous], just as He said at the third sign, and thou shalt take of the water of the river, and pour it upon the dry land, etc. It is for this reason that the words of our Rabbis can be relied upon, namely, that the first sign, [i.e., the staff turning into a serpent], was a hint to Moses that he had slandered the Israelites [when he said that they would not believe him], and the second sign was for the purpose of punishing him. And this is the sense of the expression, and Moses fled from before it [the serpent]. He feared lest he would be punished and the serpent would bite him, since every person naturally avoids danger, even though Moses knew that if it was indeed G-d’s desire [to punish him], there was no one that could deliver him out of His hand. Perhaps even though He informed Moses of the Great Name with which the world was created and everything came into existence, He wished to show him that with this Name signs and wonders would be done, changing the natural order of things, so that the matter would be firmly established in Moses’ heart and that he should in truth know that with the Great Name he will perform new things in the world. The first two signs were sufficient for Moses, and therefore the third miracle of the water [turning into blood] was not done here. Instead, G-d commanded him to do the third sign in the sight of the people.

And then Exodus 7:9

כִּי֩ יְדַבֵּ֨ר אֲלֵכֶ֤ם פַּרְעֹה֙ לֵאמֹ֔ר תְּנ֥וּ לָכֶ֖ם מוֹפֵ֑ת וְאָמַרְתָּ֣ אֶֽל־אַהֲרֹ֗ן קַ֧ח אֶֽת־מַטְּךָ֛ וְהַשְׁלֵ֥ךְ לִפְנֵֽי־פַרְעֹ֖ה יְהִ֥י לְתַנִּֽין׃

“When Pharaoh speaks to you and says, ‘Produce your marvel,’ you shall say to Aaron, ‘Take your rod and cast it down before Pharaoh.’ It shall turn into a serpent.”

On this Chizkuni says

והשלך לפני פרעה יהי לתניו, “throw it in front of Pharaoh so that it will turn into a sea monster.” The reason for this was that Pharaoh boasted of his power to the extent that G-d in Ezekiel 29,3 called him “the great sea monster.” The prophet there ridicules the actual power of Pharaoh who people were afraid of. Moses’ performing the miracle, was to show him that awe-inspiring monsters are only an illusion and can be turned into a stick by merely taking hold of their tail. Similarly, Pharaoh’s power is also only an illusion. Even though it appears that at this time he is all-powerful, this can change in the time it takes to drop a stick to the ground.

### Antwort 3 (Score: 1)

I thought I'd answered this before here but can't find it; here goes. A teacher of mine explained that nachash refers to slander and other antisocial behavior (going all the way back to Eden); Moses had slandered the people by claiming they were nonbelievers, so he was shown a nachash.

Tanin is used in the sense of the majesty of G-d's creation (including at the beginning of Genesis); the Pharaoh didn't believe in that, so he was shown a tanin.

title: Angels creation and free will
content:
# Angels creation and free will ## Frage

Where does the belief come from that angels have no free will? I have searched the scriptures and find nothing that speaks to this. Is it a belief that has entered through commentaries or traditions? There is no mention in the Scriptures that God created angels either, so how do we just accept that?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 6)

The Talmud in tractate Shabbat 89a relates the background story when Moshe was on Har Sinai that the angels were complaining and saying that they should receive the Torah and Gd tells Moshe to relate to them why they should not get the Torah and the Jewish nation should. I’ve cited the relevant point below in which Moshe says that they do not have an evil inclination (and thus free will)

…Again Moses asked: What else is written in it? God said to him: “You shall not murder, you shall not commit adultery, you shall not steal” (Exodus 20:13) Moses asked the angels: Is there jealousy among you, or is there an evil inclination within you that would render these commandments relevant? Immediately they agreed with the Holy One, Blessed be He, that He made the right decision to give the Torah to the people, and as it is stated: “God our Lord, how glorious is Your name in all the earth” (Psalms 8:10), while “that Your majesty is placed above the heavens” is not written because the angels agreed with God that it is appropriate to give the Torah to the people on earth.

We can see here proof for both points you questioned. The first, that yes Gd did create angels. The second, they do not have free will since Moshes argument as to why they should not receive the Torah is because they do not have an evil inclination, and without an evil inclination you do not have free will

Hope that helps!

### Antwort 2 (Score: 3)
  1. The Tanach, unlike the New Testament and other religious books, almost never concerns itself with anything beyond the sphere of human experience, including things pertaining to heaven and the afterlife.
  2. The angels' creation therefore is captured in the statement "And God created the heavens and...". Angels are heavenly beings, so were created when the heavens were (although Bereshit Rabbah records a tradition that they were only created on the second day, or perhaps the fifth day, in order to prevent people from claiming Hashem needed help creating the world).
  3. We are not allowed to pray to angels, e.g. Exodus 20:4. It's hard to fathom how someone could possibly argue that this is not one of, if not the major theme of the Torah - it is a mistake to bow to idols of any kind, even if you still believe in God etc.
  4. The reason we do not bow down to idols is because they do not have free will*. This is considered one of the main errors regarding idols - eyes but can't see, ears but can't hear etc.
  5. We also note that the only arena in which free will can take place is with regards to right and wrong, i.e. the Mitzvot. The Mitzvot were only given to mankind. No Mitzvot are given to angels, nowhere in the Torah does Hashem address Himself to angels.
  6. We can therefore see that it's very clear in the Torah that angels don't have "free" will. They cannot abandon their mission (and of course, there isn't a single example or hint anywhere in Torah of an angel abandoning its mission). They may have will, and consciousness (and are likely so esoteric that we cannot fathom their existence and being anyway so let's not speculate any further), but it's clear that it's not free.
  7. Can there be exceptions to this? Of course. We do have traditions of angels Hashem gave free will to as a test, and they failed. Hashem can do anything He likes, this answer is just general.
  8. Finally, that point about tradition. Please note that this is Mi Yodeya and it is highly unusual here to ask for an only-Scripture-based answer. As I wrote here (and strongly recommend you read the first part), Scripture was never meant to be standalone. Torah is supposed to be interpreted with the commentary that God gave at Sinai, and gave authority to the Sages to preserve, involve themselves with, and even develop (which they have done so so well, you'll be amazed if you take the time to look into it). See this answer for more on that and feel free to ask any questions.

Of course, the "things the Tanach doesn't concern itself with" (see point 1) will be found in this rich tradition, and this is why it's completely fair we give you an answer from the Gemara, although I hope you have enjoyed the arguments I've made from simple analysis of the Tanach in this one case.

* This is one of several reasons, but I will not get into the whole subject here

title: I don't understand why/how Hashem's language seems opposite in Bereishis 2:16-17: אָכֹ֥ל תֹּאכֵֽל you may eat& then לֹ֥א תֹאכַ֖ל you may NOT eat?
content:
# I don't understand why/how Hashem's language seems opposite in Bereishis 2:16-17: אָכֹ֥ל תֹּאכֵֽל you may eat& then לֹ֥א תֹאכַ֖ל you may NOT eat? ## Frage

I read the parshah over specifically trying to identify if Chava or the snake lied first. I remember learning that if Adam and Chava hadn't sinned by eating the forbidden fruit that the snake would not have gained power over them (full force evil inclination) and rather would have become subrserviant to their good deeds. When I read it it seems that the snake's first sentence (initially) opened the subject of Hashem's discussion but didn't actually slander Hashem directly or lie (yet). The snake's words stimulated Chava's by making a misleading statement but didn't actually say UNTRUE words (the DOUBLE negative mathmatically equates to Hashem's positive you CAN eat ALL....etc.)

Rereading it a few times in the text copied below, I noticed a seeming contradiction by HASHEM... I'm not sure how the second sentence doesn't contradict the first one like a lie. If you "MAY EAT FROM ALL OF THE TREES" then how can the next sentence explain that one is forbidden??

Here is the actual Chumash text of those verses which I found: Chabad online tanach: "16And the Lord God commanded man, saying, "Of every tree of the garden you may freely eat. טזוַיְצַו֙ יְהֹוָ֣ה אֱלֹהִ֔ים עַל־הָֽאָדָ֖ם לֵאמֹ֑ר מִכֹּ֥ל עֵֽץ־הַגָּ֖ן אָכֹ֥ל תֹּאכֵֽל: 17But of the Tree of Knowledge of good and evil you shall not eat of it, for on the day that you eat thereof, you shall surely die." יזוּמֵעֵ֗ץ הַדַּ֨עַת֙ ט֣וֹב וָרָ֔ע לֹ֥א תֹאכַ֖ל מִמֶּ֑נּוּ כִּ֗י בְּי֛וֹם אֲכָלְךָ֥ מִמֶּ֖נּוּ מ֥וֹת תָּמֽוּת:"

I looked at the question(S) that were asked about this section of the Chumash on Mi Yodeya 5 years ago]2 but not neither of those questions specifically addressed the wording and context of H" words/ language which is what I'm inquiring about here. My question in this case addresses ONLY the language in vs 16 vs. 17 with regards to Hashem's words only not the errors of Chava and/or the snake.

Related specifically to the WORDING and ORDER of the language of Chava and the snake which I looked to see how it was in line with the constant that H" encourages a person in the way they WANT to go, I suspected that Chava would have had to have been the FIRST one to say a lie to open the gate for the snake to go full scale into lie about who H" is and what H" said zone and noticed that at first the snake said his inquiry in the double negative (opposite of Hashem's positive) which only INFERS that a contradiction MAY exist but doesn't actually say that Hashem lied: in English the snake's statement would sound like "did Hashem NOT say that you can NOT eat from ALL of the trees in the Garden?" The correct answer would be "no, H" said you CAN eat from all of the fruits in the Garden", so it seems to me that the snakes first attempt was only to stir the thought that Hashem MAY have lied but not actually saying that Hashem actually lied (which never happens - right?) But if Chava HAD answered with the English response above, how could she follow with a second statement which would indicate that ONE tree wasn't included in the "ALL TREES" specified previously - which is basically my whole issue. Please help clear this up my understanding of these words if you can.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

It seems to me that you understand the two verses as being independent items. Further as @Rabbi Kaii implies you understand the translation of the second verse to be

“and as for the tree of knowledge of good and bad, you must not eat of it; for as soon as you eat of it, you shall die.”

The Torah is not written in verse form. In the Torah scroll verses are not delineated. There is no reason to see the two statements as independent. This is to be seen in the Sefaria translation that has:

but as for the tree of knowledge of good and bad, you must not eat of it; for as soon as you eat of it, you shall die.”

Note two items. [1] the verse does not begin with a capital letter; it is a continuation of the previous verse. [2] The conjunction וּ in the word וּמֵעֵ֗ץ is translated as “but”.

Thus we see that these two verses are really one statement. The second verse qualifies the statement in the first one. Thus there is no “seeming contradiction” in Hashem's words, chas vesholom.

title: Shomer Negia in Case of Danger
content:
# Shomer Negia in Case of Danger ## Frage

In a situation where two people are obligated in shomer negia (for example two single unrelated adults), if one of them is in a relatively minor state of danger, would you be allowed to get in physical contact to help them since it’s not derech chiba (affectionate), or would this only be allowed if it’s a “major” state of danger? (We would also need to define what is considered minor vs major danger but for the sake of this question let’s take the example below as minor danger)

Example: you are on a bus with an aggressive driver. A woman is standing not holding on and the bus driver slams the brakes. The woman will fall and probably sustain minor injuries if you don’t catch her. Would you be allowed to physically get in contact in order to help?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

R Moshe Feinstein (Igrot Moshe YD 2:137) writes

Even though they do not act out of sexual affection, for which reason there is no Torah prohibition, in any case, it sounds as though they are prohibited on a rabbinic level even without sexual affection, unless it is recognizable that [the touch] is not for sexual affection.

This normally happens to discussions whether it is permitted to shake a woman's hand in a business context (which some permit and some forbid, see here). It appears from his words that, in the context of a possible accident, this prohibition would not apply.

There are further analogies with a doctor allowed to touch a patient of the other genre because he is "preoccupied with his work", and therefore there is no issue of personal affection.

Of course, consult your rabbi before implementing anything you learn here.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

"Do not be overly righteous" (Ecclesiastes 7:16). If there is a woman drowning in a river and you have the means to save her, do not say, "I will let her drown because how can I go and see her nakedness?" Do not ruin yourself, be considered sinful, and be punished for it. Go and learn from Saul, who spared Agag and made a foolish argument a fortiori, and because of this he was condemned. Likewise, "one of the students of the prophets said to his fellow by the word of God, 'Strike me, please,' and the man refused to strike him" (I Kings 20:35). Because of this, he was punished, and a lion struck him and killed him (Sefer Hassidim 126).

Although the first case is "major", the last one is "minor" (although latter 2 are against a prophecy).

Bava Batra 24a, in the context of the majority vs proximity debate:

barrel of wine that was found hidden in a vineyard where there were orla grapes, and he was not concerned that the wine might be from the grapes of that vineyard (because majority trumps proximity...)

title: Wisdom and knowledge, G-dly or unG-dly?
content:
# Wisdom and knowledge, G-dly or unG-dly? ## Frage

I wondered if there are texts and/or explanations that teach us when certain knowledge or wisdom is considered G-dly or unG-dly (occult, pagan, wrong).

To give some context, I recently had a discussion with someone who believed that certain Yoga exercises and withdrawal exercises were occult because they originated in other cultures, beliefs and philosophy. Likewise, people should not learn anything from philosophy, Buddhist wisdom and other teachings.

In my view, the things, certain words or actions themselves are often not occult, pagan or unG-dly, but this is determined by context, the definition one gives to certain words, and the intention or background from which one does things determine whether something is right or wrong.

For example, if I use foreign knowledge, quote a non-Jewish teacher to proclaim or clarify my Jewish message, when I use certain examples to ultimately explain, proclaim and convey a divine message, am I in the wrong?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

The Gemara (Niddah 30b) has both, the Hachamim and Ribbi Yishmael, quoting "scientists" to prove their point and bashing the other one's proof "a proof from the fools". Seemingly they had no problem with science being used to back up their point, but at the same time, had no problem saying science is worthless when it is against the Torah.

The Rabbis also did not allow learning any form of foreign (Greek) wisdom (Sotah 9:14, Sanhedrin 10:1), but clearly knew it themselves. They warned not to hang out with people who deny God, nor go to their schools (Avot d'Ribbi Natan 2:7). The Rambam (see Kiddush HaHodesh 17:24) and the Ramban (B'reshit 9:12) say something along the lines of facts are facts when it comes to science (see Eichah Rabbah 2:13).

There is no clear line given for yes or no if it is not clearly pagan. The overall rule seems to be "Go and search for an hour that is neither part of the day nor part of the night, and learn Greek wisdom in it" (M'nachot 99b), i.e. don't go looking learning other wisdoms (since Torah is all inclusive Avot 5:22), but if you need it to understand Torah or for a job, it's fine.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

The Midrash says:

If someone tells you that there is wisdom among the nations, believe him. [If someone tells you] that there is Torah among the nations, do not believe him. [Lamentations Rabbah 2:13]

Since we must pursue wisdom, we must therefore take it wherever we find it.

### Antwort 3 (Score: 0)

Rabbi Reuven Agushevitz wrote 3 short books on philosohy, which might help draw the line: "Principles of Philosophy", "Ancient Greek Philosophy", and "Faith And Heresy".

title: Consequences of my actions, or of G-d?
content:
# Consequences of my actions, or of G-d? ## Frage

Let’s say I eat a ton of chocolate and get a big stomach ache.
Should I think that I got the stomach ache because I was stupid and ate all that food, or should I think that God gave me that stomach ache?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

Last Mishna of Berachot:

חיב אדם לברך על הרעה כשם שהוא מברך על הטובה... בכל מדה ומדה שהוא מודד לך הוי מודה לו במאד מאד

Man is obligated to bless Hashem for the bad that happens to him just as much as the good... For each and every last measure Hashem metes out to you, be exceedingly exceedingly grateful.

Everything is from Hashem.

See Tanya, Iggeret Hakodesh 25, based on the Baal Shem Tov's teachings, which explains how if a person does something wrong, and suffers as a result, the person is indeed punished, but that is not to say that the suffering was not decreed from heaven. If he had not done anything wrong, he would have suffered some other way.

See also Chulin 7b as a common reference in the Oral Torah, and for the Written Torah Mishlei 20:24:

A man's steps are from the Lord, for man understands nothing of his way.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

The answer of Rabbi Kaii is missing an additional point: we live in the world created by G-d, which follows His laws. Eating too much chocolate violates His laws of following balanced diet. The fact that one gets stomach ache is not a punishment, but a warning built into Creation of an irreparable body failure due to lack of proper nutrients if such behavior continues. Therefore, (I should quote R. Kaii's answer)...

### Antwort 3 (Score: 0)

There are a number of commentaries that speak to this issue.

Here is the Sefer Hachinuch, Mitzvah 546:

As God created His world and built it upon the foundations of the principles of nature and decreed that fire should burn and that water puts out the flame. And so too, nature requires that if a large stone falls on the head of a man, it will smash his brain; or that if a person falls from the top of a high roof to the ground, he will die. And He, may He be blessed, graced the bodies of people and blew into them a living soul with a mind, to protect the body from all incidents, and [then] placed the two of them — the soul and the body — within the sphere of the [natural] elements, and [these elements] will move them and act upon them. And since God subjugated the human body to nature — as so did His wisdom require — from the angle of its being physical, He commanded him to guard [himself] from an accident. As nature, to which he is subjugated, will act upon him if he does not guard himself from it.

Here are some other sources that either explicitly indicate that there are natural causes or can be inferred from their comments:

• Ramban

      o Commentary on Job (36:7)
      o Shaar Hagmul: Chapter 51.                                       
            
            - Chazon Yoel commentary on Shaar Hagmul
            - The Biur on the Shaar Hagmul

• Sforno: Parshat Tazria (13:47)

• Rabbenu BaChaya: Commentary on the Torah. Parshat Vayera (18:19)

• Rambam

o The Guide of the Perplexed: Book III Chapters 17,18, and 51

o Shmoneh Perakim: Eighth Perek

• Ralbag: The Wars of the Lord; Book Four: Divine Providence Chapter 1,3, and 4

• Kuzari: Fifth Essay; Chapter 20

• Rashba: Commentary on Agadot; Gemara Taanit (11a)

• Chazon Ish: Sefer Yoreh Deah; Siman 151

title: “Redundant” morning blessing?
content:
# “Redundant” morning blessing? ## Frage

Some poskim say that if you mistakenly say Zokef Kfufim before Matir Asurim, one should not go back and say Matir Asurim.[3

https://halachipedia.com/index.php?title=Birchot_HaShachar#Order_of_Brachot

From my understanding, the reason is because one bracha is included within the other so if you say the latter one first you have already given thanks to the former and therefore cannot say another bracha for something you have already said thanks for.

My question is, wouldn’t this be a ברכה שאינה צריכה, I.e a redundant, un-needed blessing and therefore we should not be saying the former bracha at all? Why is it not considered bracha she’eino tzricha?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

The Taz on Shulchan Aruch O"C 46:5 explains that the blessings were originally instituted to be said as one goes through the morning motions, i.e. Matir Asurim upon sitting up and stretching, and Zokef Kfufim upon standing upright. When each blessing is said in its proper context, they're not redundant, because they're each said at a distinct stage. But if someone forgot to say Matir Asurim, it would become redundant at the Zokef Kfufim stage and they would have to skip it.

Nowadays, we say them all together, preserving the ones that are theoretically redundant so as not to deviate from the way it was instituted by the sages. But if one accidentally said Zokef Kfufim first, it would be like one who missed the Matir Asurim blessing in its proper stage, making it now fully redundant.

title: How do we know that even doimem is being recreated from the words inside of them every instant?
content:
# How do we know that even doimem is being recreated from the words inside of them every instant? ## Frage

B"H

In the beginning of shar hayichud vihaemunah in the name of the Baal Shem Tov, it says a teaching (found also with slight variations on midrash tehillim on the verse) on the passuk "forever Hashem Your Word stands in the heavens" (tehillim 119), that the "word" that He spoke at the six days of creation to create the heavens, from nothing, initially,

"Let there be a sky in the waters to separate between water and water",

Is found (stands) inside the heavens constantly (because "His words are eternal"..), constantly creating the heavens from nothing.

It would seem like this initial teaching is already based on implications from the midrash.

But then it goes on to say a new idea, that even in doimem, inorganic matter, like rocks, and this physical earth, is also being recreated every instant from the words that He spoke at the beginning of creation that created those objects

(And even the names of objects which aren't mentioned explicitly can be derived through atbash etc.)

The question is how does the Baal Shem Tov make the connection from the midrash , that His words are inside of the heavens and constantly creating them, to the physical earth?

It doesn't explicitly mention there how it's derived, it just says it is

I was thinking it must be through one of the 13 principals of how the Torah is expounded, but I can't comprehend which one, if any.

It can't be kal vachomer because it would be more logical to say the spiritual world, heavens, which is "closer" to it's source, is being recreated from the words found inside them. But the physical earth? How do we know that?

Words of the midrash:

נאמר לעולם ה' דברך נצב בשמים. מהו דברך נצב בשמים אי זהו דבר הנצב בשמים. אלא אמר הקב"ה על מה השמים עומדים על אותו דבר שאמרתי (בראשית א ו-ז) יהי רקיע בתוך המים. ויהי כן. וכתיב (תהלים לג ט) כי הוא אמר ויהי וגו'. אותו הדבר שאמר הוא עשה. לכך נאמר (שם) הוא צוה ויעמוד. בדבר ה' שמים נעשו ובאותו הדבר שברא אותן בו הם עומדים לעולם. לכך נאמר לעולם ה' דברך נצב בשמים.

Words of the Tanya:

וּפִירֵשׁ הַבַּעַל־שֵׁם־טוֹב זִכְרוֹנוֹ לִבְרָכָה:

כִּי "דְּבָרְךָ" שֶׁאָמַרְתָּ "יְהִי רָקִיעַ בְּתוֹךְ הַמָּיִם וְגוֹ'" –

תֵּיבוֹת וְאוֹתִיּוֹת אֵלּוּ, הֵן נִצָּבוֹת וְעוֹמְדוֹת לְעוֹלָם בְּתוֹךְ רְקִיעַ הַשָּׁמַיִם,

וּמְלוּבָּשׁוֹת בְּתוֹךְ כָּל הָרְקִיעִים לְעוֹלָם לְהַחֲיוֹתָם,

כְּדִכְתִיב: "וּדְבַר אֱלֹהֵינוּ יָקוּם לְעוֹלָם",

"וּדְבָרָיו חָיִים וְקַיָּימִים לָעַד כוּ'",

כִּי אִילּוּ הָיוּ הָאוֹתִיּוֹת מִסְתַּלְּקוֹת כְּרֶגַע חַס וְשָׁלוֹם וְחוֹזְרוֹת לִמְקוֹרָן,

הָיוּ כָּל הַשָּׁמַיִם אַיִן וָאֶפֶס מַמָּשׁ, וְהָיוּ כְּלֹא הָיוּ כְּלָל,

וּכְמוֹ קוֹדֶם מַאֲמַר "יְהִי רָקִיעַ כוּ'" מַמָּשׁ.

וְכֵן בְּכָל הַבְּרוּאִים שֶׁבְּכָל הָעוֹלָמוֹת עֶלְיוֹנִים וְתַחְתּוֹנִים,

וַאֲפִילוּ אֶרֶץ הַלֵּזוּ הַגַּשְׁמִית וּבְחִינַת דּוֹמֵם מַמָּשׁ,

אִילּוּ הָיוּ מִסְתַּלְּקוֹת מִמֶּנָּה כְּרֶגַע חַס וְשָׁלוֹם הָאוֹתִיּוֹת מֵעֲשָׂרָה מַאֲמָרוֹת שֶׁבָּהֶן נִבְרֵאת הָאָרֶץ בְּשֵׁשֶׁת יְמֵי בְרֵאשִׁית,

הָיְתָה חוֹזֶרֶת לְאַיִן וָאֶפֶס מַמָּשׁ, כְּמוֹ לִפְנֵי שֵׁשֶׁת יְמֵי בְרֵאשִׁית מַמָּשׁ.

וְזֶהוּ שֶׁאָמַר הָאֲרִ"י זִכְרוֹנוֹ לִבְרָכָה, שֶׁגַּם בְּדוֹמֵם מַמָּשׁ, כְּמוֹ אֲבָנִים וְעָפָר וּמַיִם, יֵשׁ בְּחִינַת נֶפֶשׁ וְחַיּוּת רוּחָנִית.

דְּהַיְינוּ, בְּחִינַת הִתְלַבְּשׁוּת אוֹתִיּוֹת הַדִּבּוּר מֵעֲשָׂרָה מַאֲמָרוֹת הַמְחַיּוֹת וּמְהַוּוֹת אֶת הַדּוֹמֵם,

לִהְיוֹת יֵשׁ מֵאַיִן וָאֶפֶס שֶׁלִּפְנֵי שֵׁשֶׁת יְמֵי בְרֵאשִׁית.

וְאַף שֶׁלֹּא הוּזְכַּר שֵׁם "אֶבֶן" בַּעֲשָׂרָה מַאֲמָרוֹת שֶׁבַּתּוֹרָה,

אַף־עַל־פִּי־כֵן, נִמְשָׁךְ חַיּוּת לָאֶבֶן עַל יְדֵי צֵירוּפִים וְחִילּוּפֵי אוֹתִיּוֹת,

הַמִּתְגַּלְגְּלוֹת בְּרל"א שְׁעָרִים פָּנִים וְאָחוֹר, כְּמוֹ שֶׁכָּתוּב בְּסֵפֶר יְצִירָה,

עַד שֶׁמִּשְׁתַּלְשֵׁל מֵעֲשָׂרָה מַאֲמָרוֹת וְנִמְשָׁךְ מֵהֶן צֵירוּף שֵׁם "אֶבֶן",

וְהוּא חַיּוּתוֹ שֶׁל הָאֶבֶן.

וְכֵן בְּכָל הַנִּבְרָאִים שֶׁבָּעוֹלָם,

הַשֵּׁמוֹת שֶׁנִּקְרָאִים בָּהֶם בִּלְשׁוֹן הַקֹּדֶשׁ – הֵן הֵן אוֹתִיּוֹת הַדִּבּוּר, הַמִּשְׁתַּלְשְׁלוֹת מִמַּדְרֵגָה לְמַדְרֵגָה מֵעֲשָׂרָה מַאֲמָרוֹת שֶׁבַּתּוֹרָה,

עַל יְדֵי חִילּוּפִים וּתְמוּרוֹת הָאוֹתִיּוֹת בְּרל"א שְׁעָרִים, עַד שֶׁמַּגִּיעוֹת וּמִתְלַבְּשׁוֹת בְּאוֹתוֹ נִבְרָא לְהַחֲיוֹתוֹ.

לְפִי שֶׁאֵין פְּרָטֵי הַנִּבְרָאִים יְכוֹלִים לְקַבֵּל חַיּוּתָם מֵעֲשָׂרָה מַאֲמָרוֹת עַצְמָן שֶׁבַּתּוֹרָה,

שֶׁהַחַיּוּת הַנִּמְשָׁךְ מֵהֶן עַצְמָן – גָּדוֹל מְאֹד מִבְּחִינַת הַנִּבְרָאִים פְּרָטִיִּים,

וְאֵין כֹּחַ בָּהֶם לְקַבֵּל הַחַיּוּת, אֶלָּא עַל יְדֵי שֶׁיּוֹרֵד הַחַיּוּת וּמִשְׁתַּלְשֵׁל מִמַּדְרֵגָה לְמַדְרֵגָה פְּחוּתָה מִמֶּנָּה, עַל יְדֵי חִילּוּפִים וּתְמוּרוֹת הָאוֹתִיּוֹת,

וְגִימַטְרִיָּאוֹת שֶׁהֵן חֶשְׁבּוֹן הָאוֹתִיּוֹת,

עַד שֶׁיּוּכַל לְהִתְצַמְצֵם וּלְהִתְלַבֵּשׁ וּלְהִתְהַוּוֹת מִמֶּנּוּ נִבְרָא פְּרָטִי.

וְזֶה שְׁמוֹ אֲשֶׁר יִקְרְאוּ לוֹ בִּלְשׁוֹן הַקֹּדֶשׁ, הוּא כְּלִי לַחַיּוּת הַמְצוּמְצָם בְּאוֹתִיּוֹת שֵׁם זֶה,

שֶׁנִּשְׁתַּלְשֵׁל מֵעֲשָׂרָה מַאֲמָרוֹת שֶׁבַּתּוֹרָה, שֶׁיֵּשׁ בָּהֶם כֹּחַ וְחַיּוּת לִבְרוֹא יֵשׁ מֵאַיִן, וּלְהַחֲיוֹתוֹ לְעוֹלָם,

דְּ"אוֹרַיְיתָא וְקוּדְשָׁא בְּרִיךְ הוּא כּוּלָּא חַד"

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

According to the Baal Shem Tov in כתר שם טוב א קנ״ט, this is a teaching of the Arizal in Likkutei Torah, based on the Midrash where the 10 Statements of Creation are mentioned. The derivation from heavens to all of creation is that, that's what a statement is: it is the life force and entire existence of what it was spoken to create, including inorganic matter.

ותירץ האריז"ל... דארז"ל בעשרה מאמרות נברא העולם פי' ע"י המאמרות עצמן נתהוה הכל דמאמרו של הקב"ה הוא מרום וקדוש ותיכף כשאמר הקב"ה יהי רקיע נתהוה הרקיע כמ"ש בדבר ה' שמים נעשו ונכנס המאמר ההוא בחיות פנימי להחיות הרקיע כל ימות עולם שיעמוד כמ"ש לעולם ה' דברך נצב בשמים. וכן כשאמר תוצא הארץ נפש חיה או תוצא הארץ דשא ועץ פרי אותו המאמר היה מהוה הכל והמאמר הזה הוא חיות פנימי להם

The Arizal answered that... our Sages of blessed memory said "the world was created with ten statements" (Bereishit Rabba 17:1*), meaning everything came into being by the very statements of the Holy One, which are exalted and holy. Immediately when Hashem said "let there be a firmament", the firmament came into being, as it is written "By the statement of Hashem, the heavens were made" (Tehillim 33:6). I.e. the word makes the firmament, and enters it as its internal life force, standing it for all days, as it is written "Forever, Hashem Your Word stands firm in the heavens" (Tehillim 119). So too, as it is written "Let the Earth bring forth living creatures", or "let the earth sprout trees, grass and fruit trees", these statements brought everything into existence and were also the internal life for them.

Shaar HaYichud VehaEmunah discusses this idea further in chapter 3, discussing Hashem's "breath" so to speak, and you can read more about that in Alshich on Shir HaShirim 1:2. There are many sources on this idea.

The Besht gives another example of this from the Pasuk in Devarim 8:3:

כי לא על־הלחם לבדו יחיה האדם כי על־כל־מוצא פי־יהוה יחיה האדם

...for man does not live on bread alone, rather man lives on all that proceed from the mouth of Hashem.

The Besht proceeds to explain why saying a bracha with kavana before eating is what sustains us, because then we draw out the inner life of what we consume.

* see also Bamidbar Rabba 14:1 and this interesting looking page I found going through the Sfas Emes on this.

title: Inverted Nun in Haran?
content:
# Inverted Nun in Haran? ## Frage

In Rashi on the last sentence of parashat Noach, Rashi mentions a ׆ (nun hafucha) in בחרן (in Haran).‎ The Torah, however, does not have an inverted Nun there.

Why? Did Rashi use another Mesora than we do today, or is there a hidden meaning behind this? Thanks!

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 7)

Rashi did indeed have a different Mesorah, as well as many other Jews. The differences weren't as significant as those between our Mesorah and, say, the hypothesized Hebrew vorlage of the Christian LXX, but they were there. One aspect of these differences are the "אותיות משונות" (strangely-shaped letters), discussed more broadly by Moshe Rosenwasser in his paper "האותיות המשונות בתורה", Ha'Maayan 46, pp. 22-40 (link to the entire volume).

According to him, some centuries ago scribes stopped copying strangely-shaped letters and made them into regular letters. In his opinion, Rashi's backward Nun in Charan is one example of such a strangely-shaped letter.

Minchat Shai on the verse noted that the Or Torah did indeed find a Torah scroll which had a kind of decoration at the top of the Nun which made it look inverted. However, he (Minchat Shai) found evidence for the difference in the Mesorah in the Masoretic book Sefer Tagi (ספר תאגי), i.e. that according to Sefer Tagi there really should be a backward Nun in Charan.1

1 Sefer Tagi's exact words are "דאקים (or דעקים according to Minchat Shai's version) רישיהון ולא מזייני" - the דאקים version means that its head stands up and is undecorated (with ketarim/serifs) while the דעקים version means that its head is bent and is undecorated.

title: Sources for halachic advice on sensory issues/autistic traits in relation to marital intimacy
content:
# Sources for halachic advice on sensory issues/autistic traits in relation to marital intimacy ## Frage

Autism is quite common and higher functioning autism may be undiagnosed for many years. It is also possible for some people to have some autistic traits. In the context of marriage, this can be difficult due to various problems, including a lack of desire for physical affection and intimacy and/or sensory issues which can make it feel unpleasant (although not in all cases - everyone is different). Such individuals may consider themselves perfectly normal and eg. believe that the whole point in marriage is to raise a good Jewish family. They may think that the whole idea of thinking of their spouse in terms of physical desire is disgusting and not something they want to try to achieve.

As well as making מצות relating to intimacy difficult, it can be difficult for the spouse to cope with the lack of affection and physical desire from an emotional perspective. These issues can affect men and women.

Are there any ספרים (preferably in English) which deal with these sorts of issues? Ideally something which lays out what is normal in a Jewish marriage in fairly explicit unambiguous terms so that an autistic person can understand that what their spouse wants is in line with הלכה and Jewish thought?

Are there any רבנים who can be contacted (preferably anonymously) for more specific advice?

Are there any services who can help with these issues?

title: Minhag not to have the moon shine on a sleeping person?
content:
# Minhag not to have the moon shine on a sleeping person? ## Frage

I saw in a Holocaust memoir a claim by the author that in Poland there was an accepted minhag not to have the moon shine directly on a sleeping person. He mentioned it in the context of someone who was known as a Talmid Chochom doing something to avoid it (he said who the person was).

I know plenty of people who were born in the same part of Poland and who had the same general hashkafa and minhagim as this author but I never heard or saw anyone else mention such a thing.

The Mogen Avraham does say not to look at the moon during Kiddush Levana after the first glance but the (non-Kabbalistic) explanations given for that Mogen Avrohom don’t apply to sleeping in its light.

There are non-Jewish reasons given not to sleep in moon light (some believing that it impairs the quality of sleep, others just superstitions).

Is anyone familiar with such a minhag and or know why it exists, who started it etc.?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 11)

The Gemara in Pesahim 111a brings down the following:

א"ר יצחק מאי דכתיב (תהלים כג, ד) גם כי אלך בגיא צלמות לא אירא רע כי אתה עמדי זה הישן בצל דקל יחידי ובצל לבנה ובצל דקל יחידי לא אמרן אלא דלא נפיל טולא דחבריה עילויה אבל נפל טולא דחבריה עילויה לית לן בה אלא הא דתניא הישן בצל דקל יחידי בחצר והישן בצל לבנה דמו בראשו היכי דמי אי לימא דלא נפל טולא דחבריה עילויה אפילו בשדה נמי אלא לאו שמע מינה בחצר אף על גב דנפיל טולא דחבריה עילויה שמע מינה ובצילה של לבנה לא אמרן אלא במערבה אבל במדינחתא לית לן בה

R. Isaac said: What is meant by the verse, Yea, though I walk through the valley of the shadow of death, I will fear no evil, for Thou art with me? This refers to him who sleeps in the shadow of a single palm-tree or in the shadow of the moon. Now in respect to the shadow of a single palm-tree this holds good only where the shadow of the neighboring [tree] does not fall upon it; but if the shadow of the neighboring tree falls upon it, it does not matter. Then when it was taught: He who sleeps in the shadow of a single palm-tree in a courtyard and he who sleeps in the shadow of the moon, has his blood on is own head, how is it meant? Shall we say that the shadow of the neighbouring tree does not fall upon it, — then even in a field too [it is dangerous]? Hence you may surely infer from this that in a courtyard [there is danger] even if the shadow of the neighboring tree fall on it. This proves it. And in respect to the shadow of the moon too, this holds good only when [it falls] in the west, but when it is in the east it does not matter.

The Ibn 'Ezra on Psalms 121:6 states:

הלבנה בלילה תוסיף לחה מולדת תחלואים וזה דבר ברור ומנוסה

The moon at night generates phlegm and breeds diseases and this is an obvious and proven thing

R. Eliezer ha-Gadol (11th c. Germany) left the following instruction to his son (Orhoth Haim 63):

בני אל תשב בצל החמה בימי תמוז ואב וכל שכן שלא תישן בלילה לאור הלבנה ועל זה נאמר יומם השמש לא יככה וירח בלילה ביום מפני מרירי ובלילה מפני איגרת בת מחלת וכל שכן כשהלבנה בחידושה ה' ישמור את נפשך ה' ישמור צאתך ובואך מעתה ועד עולם

My son, do not dwell in the shadow of the sun in the season of Tamuz and Abh and all the more so certainly do not sleep at night in the light of the moon, and on this it was said (Psalms 121:6) "The sun shall not smite thee by day, nor the moon by night" by day because of Meriri and by night because of Agerath bath-Mahalath, and all the more so when the moon is renewed may God guard over your life and may He guard over you in your comings and goings now and forever.

The Ta'maei ha-Minhagim 464 cites the abovementioned view of R. Eliezer ha-Gadol.

Shulhan Arukh ha-Rabh (H. Shemirath ha-Nefesh 9):

ולא יישן בחצר בצל לבנה של כתל החצר, מפני שהשדים דרכם להלך בלילה, ובזמן שהלבנה זורחת מתיראין לילך במקום האור והולכין במקום הצל. ואם הלבנה במערב והוא ישן בצל הכתל במזרחו — אין לחש.

And not to sleep in a courtyard in the shadow of the moon of the wall of the courtyard, since it is the manner of shedim to so go at night, at times when the moon is shining they are afraid to go in the places of light and go instead in the shadow. And if the moon is in the west and he sleeps in the shade of the the wall to its east, there is no concern.

The Rambam and Shulhan Arukh altogether omit any such concern. Nevertheless in light of the aforementioned sources, some more recent sources take up the issue.

The Shu"T Mishnath Yosef of R. Yosef Lieberman (11, 142) holds as follows:

הנה הרשב"ם בפסחים קיא א פי' בצלה של לבנה ההולך בלילה כשהלבנה זורחת והוא הולך בצל הכתלים שדרך השדים להלוך בלילה ובזמן שהלבנה זורחת מתייראין לילך במקום האור והולכין במקום הצל עכ"ל...וא"כ הסכנה היא רק אם ישן בצל הלבנה דהיינו במקום שמוצל מאור הלבנה אבל באור הלבנה עצמה מותר לישן

The Rashbam on Pesahim 111a explains that in the shadow of the moon, one who goes at night while the moon shines and walks in the shadow of the walls, in the manner of sheidim that at night are afraid to go where the moon shines and so walk in the shade... and if that is so, the danger is only if one sleeps in the shade of the moon, which is a place protected from the light of the moon, however in the light of the moon itself it is permitted to sleep.

R. Barukh Sheraga addressing the question of whether soldiers may sleep out in the field beneath the moonlight writes (Barukh Omer YD #34):

ומדברי הגמרא נראה שהסכנה היא רק בצל הלבנה אבל לאור הלבנה אין סכנה אולם בצוואתו של רבי אליעזר הגדול כתוב שיש סכנה לישן לאור הלבנה ועל זה נאמר תהלים קכא ו יומם השמש לא יככה וירח בלילה ב וגם בדרך הטבע יש בזה קצת סכנה כמו שכתב האבן עזרא תהלים קכא ו שידוע כי השמש תזיק ברוב החום שלה והלבנה בלילה תוסיף לחה מולדת תחלואים וזה הדבר ברור ומנוסה. ולמעשה לכתחילה ראוי לחוש לזה ולישון כמקום מכוסה שהלמה אינה זורחת שם אולם כמקום הצורך אפשר להקל כזה כשם שאנחנו מקילים כזוגות מפני שהשדים אינם מצויים כינינו ג וגם הסכנה שכתב האכן עזרא כיום לא ידוע שיש כזה סכנה ויתכן שנשתנו הטכעים

From the words of the Gemara it seems that the danger is only in the shadow of the moon but that in the light of the moon there is no danger, however in the will of R. Eli'ezer ha-Gadol it is written that there is a danger to sleep in the light of the moon and it is that which is referred to in "The sun shall not smite thee by day, nor the moon by night" , and similarly within the naturalistic view there is some danger as the Ibn 'Ezra attests on Psalms 121:6 that it is known that the sun damages through the intensity of its heat and that the moon increases phlegm and brings disease and that such is clear and obvious. In practice, ab initio, it is proper to be concerned with this and to sleep in a place that is covered and where the moon doesn't shine, however in a place of need it is possible to be lenient in this in the same manner as we are lenient regarding zugoth since the sheidim are not found among us and because the danger that the Ibn 'Ezra attests to is not known to us today and perhaps nature changed.

So in short, it would be unsurprising to find certain pious minded individuals concerned for the abovementioned views avoiding sleeping in the moonlight.

title: What is the dikduk of this word?
content:
# What is the dikduk of this word? ## Frage

In Shemos 36:7, it says וְהַמְּלָאכָ֗ה הָיְתָ֥ה דַיָּ֛ם לְכׇל־הַמְּלָאכָ֖ה לַעֲשׂ֣וֹת אֹתָ֑הּ וְהוֹתֵֽר׃

I am confused as the dikduk of the last word (and I am far from a grammarian, so bear with me please…). I am looking at the website “Pealim” and the only thing I see with this conjugation is the hifil male singular imperative (https://www.pealim.com/dict/801-lehotir/). But that’s not the sense of the verse at all. All the translations translate it as descriptive (“there was left over”) as opposed to a command to leave materials over!

What is the correct understanding of the dikduk of this word?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 6)

This form is known as the infinitive absolute, which with sound verbs in hif'il takes the form הַקְטֵל. Here, we're dealing with a root whose first letter is י/ו, so we get הוֹתֵר.

Regarding meaning: the infinitive absolute is used as a noun, adverbially, replacement for a finite verb, ... Regarding ones like our case, Joüon/Muraoka write (section 123x):

The inf. abs. quite often (especially in the later books) continues a preceding form. The Waw, which usually precedes the inf. abs., sometimes has the value of a simple and, and sometimes that of and (then), indicating succession. The reasons which have motivated the choice of the inf. abs. are not clearly understood: sometimes there is probably a desire for variety or a stylistic affectation; sometimes the author wished to use a form with a vague subject like one or they. The inf. abs. virtually has the same temporal or modal value as the preceding verb.

Here, the preceding verb is היתה, a qal perfect (suffix conjugation) form, which has past tense meaning, so we attribute the same to הותר. As another example, you can see a verse with a number of infinitives absolute (bolded) in Haggai 1:6:

‮זְרַעְתֶּ֨ם הַרְבֵּ֜ה וְהָבֵ֣א מְעָ֗ט אָכ֤וֹל וְאֵין־לְשׇׂבְעָה֙ שָׁת֣וֹ וְאֵין־לְשׇׁכְרָ֔ה לָב֖וֹשׁ וְאֵין־לְחֹ֣ם ל֑וֹ וְהַ֨מִּשְׂתַּכֵּ֔ר מִשְׂתַּכֵּ֖ר אֶל־צְר֥וֹר נָקֽוּב׃

You have sowed much and brought in little; you eat without being satisfied; you drink without getting your fill; you clothe yourselves, but no one gets warm; and he who earns anything earns it for a leaky purse.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

It's basically a hiphil. The form is like הַשְׁמֵר either imperative or command or infinitive absolute, in this case the root is יתר which in hiphil becomes a ו it's probably a infinitive absolute like a semi noun the context probably means and there was enough/leftover/too much
