title: Are there still red heifers פרות אדומות in Ethiopia?
content:
# Are there still red heifers פרות אדומות in Ethiopia? ## Frage

Shulchan Orit The Halacha of Ethiopian Jewry states:

In Ethiopia, the synagogue was called masgid or beit mikdas or yetzulot bayit. People related to the synagogue with awe, as a real Temple. Villagers lived in huts, but the synagogue in every village was a stone structure, quite large, stable and respectable. The building stood out in its form, and could be seen and identified from afar. In large villages, the synagogue was built in the center of the village. It could be identified from afar by the red clay pot attached to a pole in the middle of the roof. My grandfather used to say that whoever came from afar to participate in the prayer services had great merit – long distances were not a disadvantage, but rather an advantage. The synagogue structure was divided into three parts – the courtyard, the hall, and the kadesta kedusan (kodesh ha-kodashim or “Holy of Holies”). Only the kohanim entered the Holy of Holies, and the Orit (Torah scroll) was placed there.

The public gathered in the hall. There were no chairs in the synagogue. Prayers were conducted while standing, and lasted many hours. Thus many people carried walking sticks, on which they leaned when they grew tired of standing, as in the verse, “Your rod and Your staff, they comfort me” (Psalms 23:4). The synagogue courtyard also served as a gathering place for sermons, study, offering sacrifices, reading the Torah, and any event of sacred character. The inside of the synagogue was used for prayer services only. When praying, the congregants faced Jerusalem. Before entering the synagogue, congregants removed their shoes in respect for the sanctity of the site. They spread leaves on the synagogue floor, so as not to have direct contact with the floor. Inside the Holy of Holies stood the tevot (ark), and the Orit stood on top. Next to the Orit were additional garments for the kohanim and two jars – one with ashes from the parah adumah (red heifer), the other with holy water for sprinkling on the sacrifices.

Up until the aliyah to Eretz Yisrael, the Beta Israel had a continuous tradition for the observance of all the biblical laws of purity and impurity. This included the laws of impurity relating to tumat hamet, contact with a dead body, and the means of purifying oneself from it with the ashes of the red heifer. In Ethiopia, some animals met the biblical qualifications of a parah adumah. Against this backdrop, we must ask why the rabbinic and Talmudic tradition testifies that the parah adumah no longer exists. Was it the intention of the Sages to cease the observance of all laws of purity and impurity in the wake of the destruction of the Holy Temple? Perhaps they felt that since the destruction of the Second Temple ended the use of the parah adumah in Jerusalem, therefore the practice should be halted everywhere. In Ethiopia, however, the Beta Israel were careful to observe all laws of purity and impurity as specified in the Torah.

Are there still red heifers פרות אדומות in Ethiopia today? If so, has their usage been continuous in Ethiopia? If not when did it cease?

Shulchan Orit: From Sinai to Ethiopia, Halacha of Ethiopian Jewry

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

It is doubtful there were ever any red-heifers that halakhah, as it stands within Rabbinic Judaism, would recognize (see Hilkhoth Parah). As this article in Makor Rishon explains:

ההקפדות התלמודיות הרבות בעניין כשרות פרה אדומה לא נהגו שם, וכל פרה בגוון חום בהיר נחשבה לכשרה

The many strictures regarding the kashruth of the red heifer attested to in Talmudic literature were not practiced there [in Ethiopia], and any light-brown cow was considered kosher [to the Beta Israel for this ritual purpose]

R. Menachem Waldman, a well known champion of the Beta Israel, similarly confirms (Mas'a El Shearith Yehude Itiyopia, p. 47):

לצורך היטהרות מטומאת מת הכינו אפר של פרה אדומה שלמעשה הייתה פרה חומה שנזבחה ונשרפה

For the purpose of purification from impurity imparted by death, they prepared ash from a red-heifer which in practicality/reality was a brown cow that was sacrificed and burnt

Whereas the Beta Israel understood a red-heifer to be a fairly common brown-heifer, traditional Rabbinic Judaism understands the red-heifer to be spectacularly uncommon, given the many strictures by which it may be identified. Traditionally only nine are known to have existed (H. Parah 3:):

ותשע פרות אדמות נעשו משנצטוו במצוה זו עד שחרב הבית בשניה. ראשונה עשה משה רבנו. שניה עשה עזרא. ושבע מעזרא עד חרבן הבית. והעשירית יעשה המלך המשיח מהרה יגלה אמן כן יהי רצון

Nine red heifers were offered from the time that they were commanded to fulfill this miswah until the time when the Temple was destroyed a second time. The first was brought by Moses our teacher. The second was brought by 'Ezra. Seven others were offered until the destruction of the Second Temple. And the tenth will be brought by the king Moshiah; may he speedily be revealed. Amen, so may it be God's will.

Here are some photos showing a Kes with his holy objects, which include a satchel of ash from what they deemed a red-heifer (ibid):

Dr. Steven Kaplan, one of the leading scholars on the origins of the Beta Israel, writes (The Beta Israel (Falasha) in Ethiopia, p. 196, fn. 32):

The Beta Israel laws of social purity known as attenkugn (don't touch me) are attributed to the fifteenth-century monastic leader Abba Sabra ... Given the tendency in oral traditions to date virtually all important religious institutions to his time, some caution must be exercised in dating these laws. It is difficult to discern any period in which they could have been observed strictly by all Beta Israel. Indeed, tenant farmers, soldiers, and craftsmen would all have found them an onerous burden. In all probability such laws represent an ideal for behavior practiced in reality primarily by only the monastic clergy.

Given that the evidence for this community's observance of purity laws dates back to the 15th century, it would be hard to characterize their observance as "continuous". In fact it seems that it was a practice that was not really emphasized as much until the 19th c. as a reactionary measure against Christian persecution (coming in contact with Christians was believed by them to impart impurity, thus necessitating purification via the ashes). As for when it ceased, it would seem that (at least according to the abovementioned Makor Rishon article) that the last time a red-heifer (as defined by Ethiopian custom) was slaughtered was in 1952:

הפרה האדומה האחרונה של 'ביתא ישראל' נשחטה באתיופיה בשנת 1952

The last red-heifer to be slaughtered by the Beta Israel in Ethiopia was in 1952

The practice seems to have been disbanded as a result of the wars in Ethiopia and later absorption of the community by Israel.

title: The Nachash and Bechira
content:
# The Nachash and Bechira ## Frage

How could the nachash in gan eden be punished if animals don’t have bechira (as is the implication of the Rambam Hil Teshuva 5:1, and Sanhedrin 108)?

Also, any sources would be great.
Thanks for your help

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

The snake was punished, as a stumbling block reminder to humans for their sin. (Similar to the punishment of Bil'am's donkey). As a result of the corruption caused by the sin, dealing with the snake became unsurmountable barrier, Bereshit Rabba 20:5:

Rabbi Yudan and Rabbi Huna, one of them said: [God told the serpent:] ‘You caused people to walk bent over [in grief] over their dead…

At the same time, the gemara expresses regret for snake's punishment: the snakes could help humans at delivering parcels on long distances, Sanhedrin 59b:

As it is taught in a baraita that Rabbi Shimon ben Menasya says: Woe over a great attendant that has been lost to the world; as had the snake not been cursed that it should go on its belly, there would have been two fine snakes at the disposal of each and every one of the Jewish people. One he would send to the north, and the other one he would send to the south, to bring him precious sandalbonim, a type of precious stone, and other precious stones and pearls.

I.e. had Adam and Chava did not sin, the snake would turn out to be a great help in developing the world.

title: Can a sinner volunteer for punishment?
content:
# Can a sinner volunteer for punishment? ## Frage

If a person knows that he commited an aveira (sin), and knows what the punishment is and wants the kapara (atonement), but the court does not administer the punishment due to lack of evidence, witness warning or some other technicality, can he volunteer for the punishment, e.g.:

  • A person breaks Shabbat on purpose. Can he voluneer for the death penalty?
  • A person ate blood. Can he volunteer for lashes?

Can he excommunicate himself? Can he volunteer as an Eved Yisrael?

I suppose the answer is no, a person cannot be witness to his own crimes (Yevamot 25b). Are there any special provisions to the courts, or is there any form of simply volunteering for the punishments, and if not, what is a person to do in such a situation where they genuinely do want the atonement?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

I'd combine the Gemmora in Sanhedrin 37b (also Sotah and Ktubos):

"וכן תני דבי חזקיה: מיום שחרב בית המקדש אף על פי שבטלה סנהדרי,
ארבע מיתות לא בטלו.
לא בטלו? והא בטלו? אלא דין ארבע מיתות לא בטלו:
מי שנתחייב סקילה או נופל מן הגג או חיה דורסתו מי שנתחייב שריפה או נופל בדליקה או נחש מכישו" וכו'

"..."The halakha of the four types of court-imposed capital punishment has not ceased to be applicable.

with the principle "עביד איניש דינא לנפשיה" ("a person adjudicates for himself" Bava Kamma.27b) in the lack of an authoritative Beis Din (I'm aware that the discussion covers exclusively civil law, though),

and infer that, although many would find it ethically troublesome, the answer is positive - a person can execute or lash himself.

IIRC, a Talmudic character did perform all four Capital deaths on himself to atone for his sins, and the rabbis didn't object (source needed).

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

On a more practical level - the question would be the equivalent of:

Since a perp isn't made to pay for damages if he also deserves lashes or the death penalty for the same action, does that absolve him from payment?

Rabbi David Lapin in his Matmonim shiur on Bava Metzia 91a titled Moral Conscience discusses this and states that it's clear that בדיני שמים he is obligated to pay.

So, after being killed by Beth Din, when he gets to the heavenly court, the perp will receive a punishment for not paying his victim for the monetary damages he caused.

Back to your examples, if the Bet Din doesn't administer the punishment he deserves, he would do himself a favor if he asked Rabbinic advice on how to atone for his sin.

title: If prophecy ended, how come idol worship didn't?
content:
# If prophecy ended, how come idol worship didn't? ## Frage

The Vilna Gaon claims that the destruction of the yeitzer hara (evil inclination) for idol worship also removed prophecy.

I want to know, why? It seems there is a connection between the yeitzer hara for idol worship, and the ability to prophesy. Indeed, this is what I've been taught in the past: that the temptation to Avodah Zarah, and the ability to prophesy are two sides of the same coin. However, it seem unfair.

It seems more logical that the actual ability to prophesy should be connected to the ability to worship idols, not the temptation to worship idols. Yet we find that even though we have lost the ability to prophesy, we have not lost the ability to worship idols - an unfair bargain!

So why is it the case that the inclination to idol worship is not tied to the inclination to reach the heights of prophecy, but rather it is tied to the ability to prophesy, altogether?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

My understanding is that the desire for idol worship and prophecy were both connected with a burning desire to see and feel God. When you had such a desire to be with God that you are willing to forgo all materialism (see I Sh'muel 19:24, Yesodei Hatorah 7:4), you would prophesize. (Avodah Zara was a shortcut where you would get these awesome close to god feelings without all the prep and hard work). The actions of serving God (mitzvot) are still available to do, so to are the actions of serving idols still available (and maybe some kavanot both ways).

If you look thru Navi, there are 3 types of kings: those who went in the path of David (II Kings 14:3, 16:2, 22:2), those who went in the path of Yeravam (II Kings 3:3, 13:2-4, 10:29...), and those who went in the path of Ahav (II Kings 8:27, 21:3). The first worshipped Hashem, the second worshipped Hashem but thru an illegal intermediary (calves), and the third worshipped foreign gods (baal).

The middle case of the calves seems to be not the classic Avodah Zara but more of a good Jewish boy version of Avodah Zara (I told this to someone and he said the GRA, R' Eliyahu Dessler and R' Avigdor Miller all agree but the Hazon Ish argues, no sources though).

title: If I'm not sure if I should make a bracha, should I make it?
content:
# If I'm not sure if I should make a bracha, should I make it? ## Frage

For a sheheciyanu or birchas hatov hameitiv, if I'm not sure if I should make a bracha, should you or would it be a bracha levatalah?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

Although the general rule of thumb with brachos is that ספק ברכות להקל - never to make a brachah in case of doubt, so as not to inadvertently transgress brachah l'vatalah (Shulchan Aruch OC 209:3), some say that shehechiyanu is an exception to that rule.

The Bach (OC 29) writes:

וליתא כדפי' דבספק נמי אסור לברך משום ספק ברכה לבטלה פן יהא עובר על לא תשא את שם ה' אלהיך לשוא אבל לפע"ד דאיכא לחלק בין ברכת שהחיינו לשאר ברכות דברכת שהחיינו שבאה על שמחת לבו של אדם יכול לברך אע"פ שאינו ודאי דחייב לברך דאינו עובר על לא תשא אם הוא שמח ומברך לו יתעלה על שהחייהו וקיימו עד הזמן הזה אבל כאן דמברך אשר קדשנו במצותיו וצונו וכו' פשיטא דכיון דאיכא ספק אינו יכול לברך ולומר וצונו דהויא ספק ברכה לבטלה דאסור לד"ה

The Bach posits that since shehechiyanu essentially is a berachah on simchas libo - the feeling of intense happiness - it would not be considered a berachah levatalah even if one is not obligated. Although other berachos are said on a specific occurrence/action (and in absence of that occurrence/action is levatalah), this beracha is said for an emotion.

An earlier source for this idea is in Teshuvas Rivash (505). [For further discussion of this idea, see also: Tzlach (Berachos 60a), Pri Chadash (432), Teshuvas Chasam Sofer (OC 55), and Teshuvas Tzitz Eliezer (Vol 13, Siman 20:5)]

I wrote the above because the tag was 'halacha theory'. Practically, some poskim disagree with the Bach's disctinction. For example, Mishne Berura (233:12) invokes the principle of safek berachos lehakel even by Shecheyanu. For practical ruling, as always, AYLOR!

title: How to "pasken" that AI translations are good enough to be valid translations
content:
# How to "pasken" that AI translations are good enough to be valid translations ## Frage

It seems likely that at some point soon, AI will be good at translating hebrew, yiddish, arabic and aramaic into every other language, extremely reliably.

Right now, I imagine that the general "psak"* is that one cannot use AI (or anyone but a human who has proven his worth, minimum) as a targum of Torah (even Rabbinic works), and it would take a specific type of posek, as well as a specific set of conditions, for Klal Yisrael to arrive at a widely accepted "psak"* that one can rely on AI to translate Torah.

Sorry, I can't prove these things (I am not an expert in politics or being a posek) but they seem fairly uncontroversial and straight forward to me, based on experience.

So my question is, what specific conditions, considerations and judgements need to be made in order to, and which specific authority can "pasken"* that we can rely on AI translations?

I think we are one way or another going to run into this issue soon, and it's going to be big, and impactful, so I would be glad to know.

* I put this word in quotes because this question applies on many levels, such as shnayim mikra; a political position such as Artscroll's standards or Sefaria's reliability; or the position of a kehilla or institution, such as the hashkafa of a school. Not levels all including halachic psak in the traditional sense. I want a general answer that covers all bases, ideally, but feel free to cover just one aspect of this question.

title: Source for a day for Hashem equaling 1,000 years for us
content:
# Source for a day for Hashem equaling 1,000 years for us ## Frage

Where is the source for the idea that a day for Hashem equals 1,000 years for us and what does it mean exactly (Hashem doesn't have "days", at least I don't know what that would even mean)? Is the concept used in places besides the six days of creation?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 12)

The source comes from Moses:

For a thousand years are in Your eyes like yesterday, which passed, and a watch in the night. (Psalm 90:4)

### ✅ Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

As Ezra stated, the reference given in the sources for this concept is Tehillim 90:4.

Derech Mitzvotecha Haamanut Elokut 12 explains that from above Atzilut, there is no "order of time" per se, all of time is as one. As we procede to the Sefirot of Atzilut, this unified time starts to divide. The first division is into 6 parts, each 1,000 years long (each of the 6 emotional attributes of Atzilut is the source of each 1,000 years, and the order of time arises from the fact that there is an order of Sefirot - see the source for more information). This is "Hashem's time", because the Sefirot of Atzilut represent, from our point of view, the "perspective" of Hashem, so to speak.

These further divide and divide until we get the continuum of time as we know it on the material plane. Picture, if you will, time as an upside down tree with one trunk, and then 6 branches, and these branches divide and divide and divide, and on the bottom level we have the flow of time we experience in our world.

Is it used in other places other than the 6 days of creation? It is used in Midrash Tanchuma VaYeshev 4 to explain that the Torah preceded the world by 2,000 years, due to combining Tehillim 90:4's logic with Mishlei 8:31:

[The Torah] was reared by Him and was His play thing day by day

2 days = 2,000 years.

### Antwort 3 (Score: 0)

Traditionally, the book of Psalms is said to be written by David, not Moses.

And the way I understand that verse, it doesn't put an upper limit on G-d's time factor, as time since "yesterday" can be anything from a full 47 hours and 59 minutes and 59 seconds (start of yesterday to end of today) to a tiny amount of time (end of yesterday to start of today), it does imply that 1 day counted by G-d is usually at least 500 years by our counting.

As G-d can vary His speed at will, this also makes the 6 day creation in Genesis 1 consistent with the conception of the modern cosmological and evolutionary timeline as reported by many faithful scientists . It even allows G-d to temporarily slow down to human speed to have conversations with Adam, Abraham, Israel and others, while also giving attention to believers created near other stars.

Just as G-d told Jakob a way to rear additional black sheep during the stay with Laban, He could equally have given a command for all the land based animals to evolve on Earth while He spent most of that day creating a nature in many other places .

Human counting of years didn't become accurate until late in the first scroll of the Torah, thus the seemingly impossible lifespans of early humans written there, while the time before Adam is known only from what G-d has told us from His perspective. Just as a herder of sheep does not control the placement of each straw in the mouths of the flock, G-d need not have adjusted every word about time in the Torah to reflect an accurate count of human years between events.

title: How would you respond to this claim by Christians?
content:
# How would you respond to this claim by Christians? ## Frage

My friend is an evangelical pastor and he argues that Christ could be the messiah through the female linage of Mary, I am currently struggling to respond to this and wondered how you would respond? I've included a transcript of what he said below:

The was from the direct linage of David. You say “The biological father decides which tribe the son belongs to.”. This isn’t so in Jewish tradition. Although it’s difficult to show why the Rabbis use the maternal line, nevertheless they do. So Mary's genealogy (Luke 3) is the determining factor.

You need to remember that the eligibility of Jesus for being entitled to the throne is a question for the Jews to settle. Not ‘us westerners’. Let’s look at some criteria they expect. Remember that due to the historical split, there are two distinct branches for this nation. Judah, (and Benjamin), and Israel (Northern 10 tribes).

The requirements for sitting on the throne for Judah was Davidic descendancy. No one was allowed to sit on David's throne unless he was a member of the house of David. Now the ‘key point’ here is house of David. Not bloodline.

This is crucial - because there was a curse put onto Davids bloodline. From Jeconiah. (Jeremiah 22 24-30). So Jesus couldn’t be a ‘blood’ descendant of David! That’s why Jesus couldn’t have a ‘blood’ connection to Joseph. But nevertheless had a connection to David through Joseph, as Joseph was ‘legally’ [in Jewish/Mosaic law] Jesus’s father.

So Jesus had a ‘legally accepted’ connection to the house of David through both Joseph, and Mary - and also was not ‘under’ the curse God pronounced on Jeconiah.

Now for the Northern house of Israel - to be King here, came by prophetic sanction or divine appointment. So ‘technically’ Jesus had to be eligible under two sets of requirements.

So, why or how could Jesus claim the throne of David? He was a member of the house of David apart from Jeconiah. And, He alone received divine appointment to that throne: (“The Lord God will give him the throne of his father David

I

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

You can't win of you argue this point. If you focus on minutiae, the pastor will call you a minutiae oriented Pharisee who misses the big picture.

He could say that Jesus inherits his kingship from his father, God. (Or that. David dies, God inherits him, passes to his son). Remember, protestants don't have a stodgy pope holding their theology in check.

Jesus's non Messiahship is based on his failure to actually rule, ingather exiles, revive all of the dead (not just a few people) etc. its the big things that matter.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

God's word in the Hebrew Bible indicates that Tribal affiliation is patrilinear.

Numbers 1:2

Take the sum of all the congregation of the children of Israel, by families following their fathers' houses.

Ibid. 1:18

and they assembled all the congregation on the first day of the second month, and they declared their pedigrees according to their families according to their fathers' houses.

Ezra 2:59

but they could not tell their fathers' houses and their children, if they were from Israel.

Given the great lengths the gospel writers went to spell out Jesus' "exact" genealogy from David, they were evidently well aware that according to Biblical Law tribal affiliation goes exclusively via the father, and they intended to establish that.

In both putative genealogies of Jesus; in Matthew 1:6, and the other in Luke 3:31, the ancestry of David is mentioned ... for Jesus (not Mary).

Consider also Luke 1:27, which plainly asserts that it is Joseph who was from the House of David, not Mary.

Moreover, in Luke 2:4, the author writes that the reason it was necessary for Joseph and Mary to return to Bethlehem, was because it was Joseph, not Mary, who was from the House of David.

According to the Hebrew Bible, the Messiah will be a patrilineal descendant of King David, something that Jesus could never be; since according to the legend of the virgin birth, he did not have a biological father.

There is no basis in Jewish law for a father passing on his tribal line by adoption. So Joseph adopting baby Jesus, who allegedly had no Jewish tribal lineage, could not make Jesus part of Joseph's tribe.

title: How many nazirites are there in the world today?
content:
# How many nazirites are there in the world today? ## Frage

It is very easy to make a nazirite vow, all that is required is, “he made a decision in his heart to take a nazirite vow and verbally expressed concepts that suggest this intent.” Mishnah Torah, Nazariteship 1:5.

But due to the lack of a Temple, “when a person takes a nazirite vow in the present era, he must observe it forever, because we do not have a Temple where he can go and offer his sacrifices at the conclusion of his nazirite vow.” Id. 2:20.

So it is logical that there must be many nazirites in the world today. Are there any figures or educated guesses on how many?
